cards.rawHeader: Corporations 001. Pre Incorporation
cards.backPlain: Promoter liability for pre-incorporation agreements: 0.1 A promoter is personally liable for knowingly acting on behalf of a corporation (C) before incorporation, and remains liable after C comes into existence, unless: 0.1.1 There is a subsequent novation releasing the promoter from liability. 0.1.2 The third party agrees to look only to C for performance. 0.1.3 The promoter had no actual knowledge that the corporation's charter has not yet been issued. Fiduciary duty: a promoter can be liable to C for violating fiduciary duties. Compensation: a promoter may seek compensation or reimbursement for related expenses, but cannot compel C to pay because the acts were not undertaken at C's direction.
cards.frontPrompt: What is a promoter, when is a promoter personally liable on pre-incorporation contracts, and how can that liability be avoided? Also, what fiduciary and compensation rules apply to promoters?
cards.cloze: {{c1::Promoter liability}} for pre-incorporation agreements: 0.1 A {{c2::promoter}} is {{c3::personally liable}} for knowingly acting on behalf of a {{c4::corporation (C) before incorporation}}, and remains liable after C comes into existence, unless: 0.1.1 There is a subsequent {{c5::novation}} releasing the promoter from liability. 0.1.2 The {{c6::third party agrees to look only to the corporation for performance}}. 0.1.3 The promoter had {{c7::no actual knowledge that the corporation's charter has not yet been issued}}. {{c8::Fiduciary duty}}: a promoter can be liable to C for violating fiduciary duties. {{c9::Compensation}}: a promoter may seek compensation or reimbursement for related expenses, but {{c10::cannot compel the corporation to pay}} because the acts were not undertaken at C's direction.
cards.easyContent: A promoter who enters contracts on behalf of a not-yet-formed corporation is personally liable on those contracts unless there is a novation, the third party agrees to look only to the corporation, or the promoter lacked actual knowledge that the corporation was not yet formed.
cards.mediumContent: A promoter is personally liable when knowingly acting on behalf of a corporation before incorporation and remains liable even after the corporation comes into existence, unless (1) a novation substitutes the corporation and releases the promoter, (2) the third party agrees to look solely to the corporation for performance, or (3) the promoter had no actual knowledge that the charter had not been issued. Promoters owe fiduciary duties to the corporation and can be liable for breach. They may seek compensation or reimbursement for expenses but cannot force the corporation to pay for acts not authorized by it.
cards.hardContent: Promoters are individuals who act on behalf of a proposed corporation before it is formed. A promoter is personally liable for contracts and other pre-incorporation agreements entered into while knowingly acting for the corporation before incorporation, and that liability continues even after the corporation comes into existence. The promoter avoids or terminates this liability only if: (1) there is a novation substituting the corporation as obligor and expressly releasing the promoter; (2) the third party, at the outset or later, agrees to look only to the corporation for performance; or (3) the promoter lacked actual knowledge that the corporation’s charter had not yet been issued. Promoters owe fiduciary duties of loyalty and fair dealing to the corporation and may be liable to it for breaches of those duties. Although promoters may seek compensation or reimbursement for expenses incurred in forming the corporation, they cannot compel the corporation to pay because their acts were not taken at the corporation’s direction prior to formation.
cards.mnemonic: PLN: Promoter liable until Novation, party Looks only to corp, or No knowledge.
cards.clozeLite: A {{c1::promoter}} who {{c2::knowingly acts for a corporation before incorporation}} is personally liable until {{c3::novation}}, {{c4::third party looks only to the corporation}}, or {{c5::no actual knowledge of non-formation}}.

cards.subject: Corporations
cards.rawHeader: Corporations 002. Pre Incorporation
cards.backPlain: Corporation's liability for pre-incorporation contracts: 1. General rule: C is not liable for pre-incorporation transactions, even those for the benefit of C, because there is no principal–agent relationship. 2. Adoption: C is liable if it expressly or impliedly adopts a contract by: 2.1 Accepting the benefits of the transaction, or 2.2 Giving an express acceptance of liability for the debt.
cards.frontPrompt: Before incorporation, is a corporation liable on pre-incorporation contracts, and how can it become liable through adoption?
cards.cloze: Corporation's liability for pre-incorporation contracts: 1. {{c1::General rule}}: {{c2::The corporation is not liable}} for pre-incorporation transactions, even those for its benefit, because there is {{c3::no principal–agent relationship}}. 2. {{c4::Adoption}}: The corporation becomes liable if it {{c5::expressly or impliedly adopts}} a contract by: 2.1 {{c6::Accepting the benefits of the transaction}}, or 2.2 {{c7::Giving an express acceptance of liability for the debt}}.
cards.easyContent: A corporation is not automatically liable on pre-incorporation contracts because it did not yet exist, but it can become liable if it later adopts the contract, such as by accepting its benefits or expressly assuming the obligation.
cards.mediumContent: By default, a corporation is not liable on pre-incorporation contracts, even if they were made for its benefit, because no principal–agent relationship existed before formation. However, the corporation can become liable if it adopts the contract, either expressly (for example, by a board resolution assuming the debt) or impliedly (for example, by accepting the benefits of the transaction).
cards.hardContent: A corporation does not incur liability for pre-incorporation contracts or other transactions entered into on its behalf before it legally exists, even if those contracts benefit the corporation, since there is no principal–agent relationship before incorporation. Nonetheless, once formed, the corporation may adopt a pre-incorporation contract and thereby become liable on it. Adoption may be express, such as when the board passes a resolution assuming the contract or expressly agreeing to pay the debt, or implied, such as when the corporation knowingly accepts and retains the benefits of the pre-incorporation transaction. Adoption does not, by itself, release the promoter from liability absent a novation.
cards.mnemonic: Corp needs to ADOPT to be ADOPT-able: No adoption, no obligation.
cards.clozeLite: A corporation is {{c1::not automatically liable}} on {{c2::pre-incorporation contracts}}, but can become liable by {{c3::express}} or {{c4::implied adoption}}.

cards.subject: Corporations
cards.rawHeader: Corporations 003. Corporation Characteristics
cards.backPlain: A corporation is a legal entity that is separate from its owners. Corporations have the following general characteristics: 1. Centralized management: management rights are centralized in a board of directors (BoD), who delegate day-to-day management to corporate officers. Unlike partnerships, management is generally not spread among owners (i.e., shareholders). 2. Limited liability: only the corporation itself can be liable for its obligations; shareholders, board members, and officers are generally not personally liable for the corporation's obligations. 3. Transferability of ownership: shareholders can freely transfer their ownership interests (i.e., shares) unless prohibited by the articles of incorporation or bylaws. 4. Continuity: corporations can exist in perpetuity; changes in ownership do not affect the corporation's existence. 5. Personhood: corporations are considered legal persons for most intents and purposes and are entitled to certain constitutional protections (e.g., due process and equal protection).
cards.frontPrompt: What are the key characteristics that distinguish a corporation from other business forms such as partnerships?

Unlike partnerships, management is generally not spread among owners (i.e., shareholders). 2. {{c6::Limited liability}}: only the corporation itself can be liable for its obligations; {{c7::shareholders, board members, and officers are generally not personally liable}} for the corporation's obligations. 3. {{c8::Transferability of ownership}}: shareholders can freely transfer their ownership interests (i.e., shares) unless prohibited by the {{c9::articles of incorporation or bylaws}}. 4. {{c10::Continuity}}: corporations can {{c11::exist in perpetuity}}; changes in ownership do not affect the corporation's existence. 5. {{c12::Personhood}}: corporations are considered {{c13::legal persons}} for most intents and purposes and are entitled to certain {{c14::constitutional protections}} (e.g., {{c15::due process and equal protection}}).
cards.easyContent: A corporation is a separate legal person with centralized management in a board of directors, limited liability for owners, freely transferable shares (absent restrictions), continuity of existence, and certain constitutional rights.
cards.mediumContent: Corporations are separate legal entities whose key features include: (1) centralized management by a board of directors and officers, rather than by all owners; (2) limited liability, meaning shareholders and managers are generally not personally liable for corporate debts; (3) generally free transferability of shares unless restricted by the articles or bylaws; (4) continuity of existence regardless of changes in ownership; and (5) legal personhood, which gives corporations certain constitutional protections such as due process and equal protection.
cards.hardContent: A corporation is a legal entity distinct from its owners and is characterized by several core attributes. First, management is centralized in a board of directors (BoD), which oversees major decisions and delegates day-to-day operations to corporate officers; unlike partnerships, shareholders do not ordinarily manage. Second, owners and managers enjoy limited liability: the corporation alone is responsible for its debts and obligations, and shareholders, directors, and officers are generally not personally liable. Third, ownership interests—shares—are generally freely transferable unless the articles of incorporation or bylaws impose restrictions. Fourth, corporations have continuity of life and may exist in perpetuity; changes in shareholder ownership do not terminate the entity. Fifth, corporations are treated as legal persons, capable of owning property, suing and being sued, and receiving certain constitutional protections such as due process and equal protection.
cards.mnemonic: CLTCP: Centralized, Limited liability, Transfer, Continuity, Personhood.
cards.clozeLite: Core corporate traits: {{c1::centralized management}}, {{c2::limited liability}}, {{c3::free transferability of shares}}, {{c4::continuity of existence}}, and {{c5::legal personhood}}.

cards.subject: Corporations
cards.rawHeader: Corporations 004. Formation
cards.backPlain: A corporation is formed when articles of incorporation are filed with the state. A corporation formed in accordance with applicable laws is a de jure corporation. 1. Articles of incorporation (must include): 1.1 Name: the corporate name. 1.2 Shares: the maximum number of shares the corporation is authorized to issue. 1.3 Incorporators: the names and addresses of each person who forms the corporation. 1.4 Registered office and agent: the name and address of the initial registered agent and registered office. 1.5 Optional provisions: the articles can include any other provisions regarding management, as long as they are legal. 2. Statement of purpose: 2.1 Some states require a statement regarding the corporation's purpose. 2.2 Most corporations use boilerplate language allowing the corporation to take any action necessary to carry out its business or affairs. 2.3 A corporation that includes a narrow purpose in its articles cannot take action unrelated to that purpose. 3. Bylaws: written rules for managing the corporation, which provide for ordinary business conduct (e.g., election of board members, meeting times, etc.). 3.1 Must be adopted by the incorporators or the board of directors. 3.2 Shareholders can amend initial bylaws. 3.3 Bylaws can contain any provision for managing and regulating the corporation's affairs as long as it is legal. 3.4 In conflicts between bylaws and the articles of incorporation, the articles control.
cards.frontPrompt: How is a de jure corporation formed, what must the articles of incorporation contain, and what is the role of the statement of purpose and bylaws?

A corporation formed in accordance with applicable laws is a {{c2::de jure corporation}}. 1. {{c3::Articles of incorporation}} (must include): 1.1 {{c4::Name}}: the corporate name. 1.2 {{c5::Shares}}: the maximum number of shares the corporation is authorized to issue. 1.3 {{c6::Incorporators}}: the names and addresses of each person who forms the corporation. 1.4 {{c7::Registered office and agent}}: the name and address of the initial registered agent and registered office. 1.5 {{c8::Optional provisions}}: the articles can include any other provisions regarding management, as long as they are legal. 2. {{c9::Statement of purpose}}: 2.1 Some states require a statement regarding the corporation's purpose. 2.2 Most corporations use {{c10::boilerplate language}} allowing the corporation to take any action necessary to carry out its business or affairs. 2.3 A corporation that includes a {{c11::narrow purpose}} in its articles {{c12::cannot take action unrelated to that purpose}}. 3. {{c13::Bylaws}}: written rules for managing the corporation, which provide for ordinary business conduct (e.g., election of board members, meeting times, etc.). 3.1 Must be adopted by the {{c14::incorporators or the board of directors}}. 3.2 {{c15::Shareholders can amend}} initial bylaws. 3.3 Bylaws can contain any provision for managing and regulating the corporation's affairs as long as it is {{c16::legal}}. 3.4 In conflicts between bylaws and the articles of incorporation, the {{c17::articles}} control.
cards.easyContent: A de jure corporation is created by filing articles of incorporation with the state that include required information such as the name, authorized shares, incorporators, and registered agent, and it is governed in day-to-day matters by bylaws consistent with the articles.
cards.mediumContent: To form a de jure corporation, incorporators file articles of incorporation with the state. The articles must state the corporate name, the maximum authorized shares, the names and addresses of incorporators, and the initial registered office and agent, and may include other lawful management provisions. Some states also require a statement of corporate purpose; most corporations use a broad purpose clause, but a narrow purpose clause limits corporate actions. Bylaws are internal rules governing ordinary corporate operations; they are adopted by incorporators or the board, may be amended by shareholders, and are valid so long as they are lawful and do not conflict with the articles, which control in any conflict.
cards.hardContent: A de jure corporation is formed when the incorporators properly file articles of incorporation with the appropriate state office in compliance with statutory requirements. The articles must at least identify: (1) the corporate name; (2) the maximum number of shares the corporation is authorized to issue; (3) the names and addresses of the incorporators; and (4) the name and address of the initial registered agent and registered office. The articles may also include other lawful provisions regarding corporate management. Many states require the articles to state the corporation’s purpose. Most corporations use a broad, boilerplate purpose clause that permits any lawful business activity; when the articles state a narrow purpose, the corporation is restricted from acting outside that purpose. Bylaws are written rules for the internal governance of the corporation—such as election of directors and meeting procedures—adopted by the incorporators or the board and amendable by shareholders. Bylaws may address any lawful matter related to corporate management but, in any conflict between bylaws and the articles of incorporation, the articles control.
cards.mnemonic: Articles: N SIR—Name, Shares, Incorporators, Registered agent/office.
cards.clozeLite: To form a {{c1::de jure corporation}}, incorporators file {{c2::articles of incorporation}} stating {{c3::name}}, {{c4::authorized shares}}, {{c5::incorporators and registered agent}}, with {{c6::bylaws}} governing internal operations.

cards.rawHeader: Corporations 005. Pre Incorporation Transactions and Liability
cards.front: Pre Incorporation Transactions and Liability – Overview
cards.backPlain: Pre-incorporation transactions involve promoters acting on behalf of a not-yet-formed corporation, entering into contracts and arrangements to obtain capital and plan the business. By default, the promoter is personally liable on these pre-incorporation contracts, and the corporation is not liable unless it later adopts the contracts. Promoter liability can change after incorporation: (1) a novation can substitute the corporation as the obligor and release the promoter, and (2) the corporation may agree to indemnify the promoter if he is held liable. The corporation itself becomes liable on pre-incorporation contracts only if it expressly or impliedly adopts them, such as by board resolution or by accepting benefits. Subscription agreements are a common type of pre-incorporation or early-stage financing contract under which a person agrees to buy a specified number of shares from the corporation at a stated price.
cards.frontPrompt: In corporate law, what are the key rules governing pre-incorporation transactions: the role of promoters, promoter liability and its exceptions, corporate liability and adoption, and the nature of subscription agreements?
cards.cloze: Pre-incorporation transactions involve {{c1::promoters}} acting on behalf of a {{c2::not-yet-formed corporation}} to obtain capital and plan the business. By default, the {{c3::promoter is personally liable}} on pre-incorporation contracts, and the {{c4::corporation is not liable}} unless it later {{c5::adopts}} the contracts. Promoter liability can change after incorporation through {{c6::novation}} (substituting the corporation and releasing the promoter) and {{c7::indemnification}} (the corporation agreeing to reimburse the promoter if he is held liable). The corporation becomes liable only if it {{c5::expressly or impliedly adopts}} the contract. A {{c8::subscription agreement}} is a contract under which a person agrees to {{c9::purchase a specified number of shares from the corporation at a stated price}}.
cards.easyContent: Pre-incorporation transactions center on promoters, who act for a not-yet-formed corporation. Promoters are personally liable on pre-incorporation contracts unless released by novation, while the corporation is not liable unless it later adopts the contract. A subscription agreement is a promise to buy shares from the corporation at a set price.
cards.mediumContent: Pre-incorporation transactions involve promoters entering contracts and making arrangements on behalf of a not-yet-formed corporation to obtain capital and plan operations. The promoter is personally liable on pre-incorporation contracts and remains liable after incorporation unless there is a novation that releases him and substitutes the corporation; the corporation may also agree to indemnify him. By default, the corporation is not liable on these contracts unless it expressly or impliedly adopts them, for example by board resolution or accepting benefits. A subscription agreement is a contract in which a person agrees to buy a specified number of shares from the corporation at an agreed price, often in connection with formation or financing.
cards.hardContent: Pre-incorporation transactions arise when promoters act on behalf of a not-yet-formed corporation to secure capital and plan the business structure, often becoming incorporators. The promoter is personally liable on contracts entered into on behalf of the future corporation and remains personally liable even after incorporation, unless all parties agree to a novation that releases the promoter and substitutes the corporation as the obligor. The corporation may separately agree to indemnify the promoter if he is held liable. As a general rule, the corporation is not liable on pre-incorporation contracts; it becomes liable only if it adopts the contract, either expressly (such as through a board resolution) or impliedly (such as by knowingly accepting the contract’s benefits). Subscription agreements are a common pre-incorporation or early financing device in which an investor agrees to purchase a specified number of shares from the corporation at a set price.
cards.mnemonic: PALN: Promoter Always Liable; Novation needed.

cards.subject: Corporations
cards.topic: Ulta Vires Acts and De Facto Corporations
cards.rawHeader: Corporations 006. Ulta Vires Acts and De Facto Corporations
cards.front: Ulta Vires Acts, De Facto Corporations, and Corporation by Estoppel
cards.backPlain: Overview: 1. Ultra vires acts - An ultra vires act is when a corporation acts outside the purposes stated in its articles of incorporation. - Remedies: shareholders may seek to enjoin the act, the corporation may seek damages from responsible officers/directors, and the state may seek dissolution. 2. De facto corporation - Even if incorporation is defective, an entity may be treated as a de facto corporation (and thus as if properly incorporated) if statutory, good faith, and "acting like a corporation" requirements are met. 3. Corporation by estoppel - Persons who have treated an entity as a corporation may be estopped from denying its corporate status when attempting to avoid liability.
cards.frontPrompt: What are ultra vires acts, and how do de facto corporation and corporation by estoppel doctrines protect entities with formation defects?
cards.cloze: 1. {{c1::Ultra vires acts}}: when a corporation acts {{c2::outside the purposes stated in its articles of incorporation}}, with potential {{c3::shareholder injunctions}}, {{c4::corporate suits for damages}}, and {{c5::state dissolution}}. 2. {{c6::De facto corporation}}: treats an entity with {{c7::defective formation}} as a corporation if key requirements are met. 3. {{c8::Corporation by estoppel}}: parties who {{c9::treat an entity as a corporation}} are {{c10::estopped from denying}} its corporate status to avoid liability.
cards.easyContent: This card gives an overview of three doctrines: (1) ultra vires acts (corporate actions beyond stated purposes and their remedies), (2) de facto corporations (defectively formed but treated as corporations if certain requirements are met), and (3) corporation by estoppel (parties who treat an entity as a corporation cannot later deny its status to escape liability).
cards.mediumContent: Ultra vires acts are corporate actions beyond the purposes in the articles, with three main remedies: shareholder injunction, corporate suit against responsible officers/directors for damages, and possible state dissolution. A de facto corporation is a defectively formed entity that is nonetheless treated as a corporation if statutory, good faith, and "acting like a corporation" requirements are satisfied. Corporation by estoppel prevents parties who have treated an entity as a corporation from later denying its corporate status to avoid liability.
cards.hardContent: This parent card summarizes: (1) ultra vires acts—corporate conduct outside the purposes stated in the articles of incorporation and the associated remedies (shareholder injunction, corporate suit for damages against responsible officers/directors, and potential state dissolution); (2) de facto corporation—treatment of a defectively formed business as a corporation when there is a valid incorporation statute, a good faith attempt to comply, and conduct in corporate form; and (3) corporation by estoppel—doctrine that estops parties who have treated an entity as a corporation from denying its corporate existence to escape liability.
cards.mnemonic: De facto L-G-A: Law, Good faith, Acting corporate; ultra vires S-C-S: Shareholder, Corporate suit, State.
cards.atomizationNotes: Split into three children: (1) ultra vires definition and consequences, (2) de facto corporation definition and requirements, and (3) corporation by estoppel rule.
cards.clozeLite: A {{c1::de facto corporation}} needs a {{c2::valid statute}}, {{c3::good faith attempt to comply}}, and {{c4::acting like a corporation}}.

cards.subject: Corporations
cards.rawHeader: Corporations 007. Piercing the Corporate Veil
cards.backPlain: 1. General rule and exception 1.1 General rule: Shareholders, directors, and officers are not personally liable for corporate obligations. 1.2 Exception – piercing the corporate veil: They can be held personally liable under the doctrine of piercing the corporate veil. 1.3 Consequence: When the corporate veil is pierced, the corporate entity is disregarded in order to hold shareholders, officers, directors, and others personally liable. 2. Acts justifying piercing the veil (courts will pierce the corporate veil where): 2.1 Ignoring corporate formalities / alter ego: Where a shareholder dominates the corporation to the extent that the corporation is not being treated as a separate entity, i.e., the corporation is being used as an alter ego of the shareholders, resulting in some basic injustice. 2.2 Inadequate capitalization: The corporation was undercapitalized (i.e., underfunded) at the time of incorporation. This is not established by insolvency alone, but insolvency shortly after formation is a prime indicator of inadequate capitalization. 2.3 Fraud or illegality: The corporate entity may be disregarded if there is fraud or other illegality, to prevent fraud or other illegality, or to prevent a shareholder from using the corporation to avoid existing personal liabilities. 3. Scope of liability 3.1 Once the corporate veil is pierced, persons composing the corporation may be held personally liable, but usually only those involved in active management will be held liable.
cards.frontPrompt: What is the general rule of limited liability in corporations, and under what circumstances will a court pierce the corporate veil to impose personal liability on shareholders or managers?
cards.cloze: 1. General rule and exception 1.1 General rule: {{c1::Shareholders, directors, and officers are not personally liable for corporate obligations}}. 1.2 Exception – {{c2::piercing the corporate veil}}: They can be held personally liable under the doctrine of piercing the corporate veil. 1.3 Consequence: When the corporate veil is pierced, the {{c3::corporate entity is disregarded}} in order to hold shareholders, officers, directors, and others personally liable. 2. Acts justifying piercing the veil (courts will pierce the corporate veil where): 2.1 {{c4::Ignoring corporate formalities / alter ego}}: Where a shareholder dominates the corporation to the extent that the corporation is not being treated as a separate entity, i.e., the corporation is being used as an {{c5::alter ego of the shareholders}}, resulting in some basic injustice. 2.2 {{c6::Inadequate capitalization}}: The corporation was undercapitalized (underfunded) at the time of incorporation. This is not established by insolvency alone, but insolvency shortly after formation is a prime indicator of inadequate capitalization. 2.3 {{c7::Fraud or illegality}}: The corporate entity may be disregarded if there is fraud or other illegality, to prevent fraud or other illegality, or to prevent a shareholder from using the corporation to {{c8::avoid existing personal liabilities}}. 3. Scope of liability 3.1 Once the corporate veil is pierced, persons composing the corporation may be held {{c9::personally liable}}, but usually only those involved in {{c10::active management}} will be held liable.
cards.easyContent: Corporations generally shield shareholders, directors, and officers from personal liability, but a court may pierce the corporate veil and impose personal liability where owners abuse the corporate form, such as by ignoring formalities, undercapitalizing the corporation, or using it to perpetrate fraud.
cards.mediumContent: The default rule is that shareholders, directors, and officers are not personally liable for corporate debts. Under the piercing-the-corporate-veil doctrine, a court may disregard the corporate entity and impose personal liability where owners treat the corporation as their alter ego by ignoring formalities, where the corporation is inadequately capitalized at formation, or where the corporation is used to perpetrate fraud or illegality or to avoid existing personal liabilities. If the veil is pierced, those involved in active management are usually the ones held personally liable.
cards.hardContent: Shareholders, directors, and officers are generally not personally liable for corporate obligations because the corporation is treated as a separate legal entity. However, under the doctrine of piercing the corporate veil, a court may disregard the corporate entity and impose personal liability where equity demands it. Factors justifying veil piercing include: (1) ignoring corporate formalities and using the corporation as an alter ego of the shareholders so that there is no real separation and some basic injustice would result, (2) inadequate capitalization at the time of incorporation, often evidenced by insolvency soon after formation, and (3) fraud or other illegality, including using the corporation to shield existing personal liabilities. When the veil is pierced, the individuals composing the corporation may be held personally liable, typically limited to those involved in active management and responsible for the abuse.
cards.mnemonic: AIF: Alter ego, Inadequate capital, Fraud/illegality.
cards.clozeLite: Under {{c1::limited liability}}, {{c2::shareholders, directors, and officers}} aren’t personally liable, unless {{c3::piercing the corporate veil}} applies for {{c4::alter ego}}, {{c5::inadequate capitalization}}, or {{c6::fraud/illegality}}.

cards.topic: Corporate Securities and Classes of Shares
cards.rawHeader: Corporations 008. Corporate Securities and Classes of Shares
cards.front: Corporate Securities and Classes of Shares
cards.backPlain: 1. Overview of corporate securities 1.1 Corporations obtain funding by issuing securities, which are of two main types: debt and equity. 2. Debt securities (bonds) 2.1 Definition: With debt securities, the corporation borrows funds from an outside creditor and promises to repay the creditor. 2.2 Holders of debt securities have no ownership interest in the corporation. 3. Equity securities (stock) 3.1 Definition: Equity securities (stock) represent investment in the corporation; holders (shareholders) become part owners of the corporation. 3.2 Authorized shares: The maximum number of shares the corporation may issue, as prescribed in the articles of incorporation. 3.3 Issued/outstanding shares: Shares that have been sold to investors and are currently held by them. 3.4 Reacquired shares: Shares that the corporation buys back; these revert from being issued/outstanding to authorized but unissued. 4. Classes of shares 4.1 Corporations may choose to issue different classes of stock; each class of shares can have different series within a class. 5. Articles requirements for share classes 5.1 The articles of incorporation must authorize each class and set forth: 5.1.1 The number of shares of each class. 5.1.2 The name or distinguishing designation for each class. 5.1.3 A description of the rights, preferences, and/or limitations afforded to each class of shares.
cards.frontPrompt: What are the two main types of corporate securities, how do debt and equity securities differ, and what must the articles of incorporation specify about classes of stock?
cards.cloze: 1. Articles requirements for share classes 5.1 The {{c16::articles of incorporation}} must authorize each class and set forth: 5.1.1 The {{c17::number of shares}} of each class. 5.1.2 The {{c18::name or distinguishing designation}} for each class. 5.1.3 A description of the {{c19::rights, preferences, and/or limitations}} afforded to each class of shares.
cards.easyContent: Corporations raise money by issuing debt (bonds, which create creditor rights but no ownership) and equity (stock, which makes holders owners). The articles of incorporation must authorize each class of stock and describe how many shares it has, how it is designated, and its rights and limitations.
cards.mediumContent: Corporate securities are mainly debt and equity. Debt securities (such as bonds) involve the corporation borrowing money from creditors and promising repayment; debt holders have no ownership interest. Equity securities (stock) represent an ownership investment; shareholders become part owners. Within equity, there are authorized shares (the maximum allowed by the articles), issued/outstanding shares (sold and held by investors), and reacquired shares (bought back and returned to authorized but unissued status). Corporations can issue multiple classes and series of stock, and the articles must authorize each class and state the number of shares, its name or designation, and the rights, preferences, and limitations of that class.
cards.hardContent: Corporations finance their operations by issuing securities, primarily of two types: debt and equity. Debt securities, such as bonds, reflect a borrowing relationship in which the corporation receives funds from an outside creditor and promises to repay; holders have no ownership interest. Equity securities (stock) represent an ownership interest; shareholders are part owners of the corporation. Equity can be divided into authorized shares (the maximum number permitted in the articles), issued/outstanding shares (those actually sold and held), and reacquired shares (shares repurchased by the corporation that revert to authorized but unissued status). Corporations may create multiple classes of stock and even different series within a class. The articles of incorporation must authorize each class and specify the number of shares, the name or distinguishing designation, and the particular rights, preferences, and limitations associated with each class.

cards.clozeLite: Corporate securities are mainly {{c1::debt}} and {{c2::equity}}. Debt holders are {{c3::creditors with no ownership}}; equity holders are {{c4::owners (shareholders)}}. Articles must {{c5::authorize each class and state its shares, designation, and rights/preferences/limitations}}.

cards.topic: Varying Rights in Shares and Consideration for Shares
cards.rawHeader: Corporations 009. Varying Rights in Shares and Consideration for Shares
cards.front: Varying Rights in Shares and Consideration for Shares
cards.backPlain: 1. Varying rights in share classes 1.1 Shares authorized by a corporation can have different rights, preferences, and limitations depending on the class of shares. 1.2 The articles can define almost any kind of differentiation between share classes. 1.3 Common differences between share classes involve: 1.3.1 Rights to distributions and/or dividends. 1.3.2 The nature of voting rights. 1.3.3 Preference with regard to distributions. 2. Distribution rights 2.1 A corporation can distribute assets in the form of dividends, redemption of shares, or liquidating distributions upon dissolution. 2.2 At least one class of shares must be entitled to receive the corporation’s net assets upon dissolution. 2.3 Board discretion: The decision whether to declare a distribution is within the board of directors’ sole discretion, even where the articles authorize distributions. 2.4 Shareholders have no general right to demand a distribution. 3. Consideration for shares 3.1 Shares can be issued by the corporation in exchange for any tangible or intangible property or benefit to the corporation. 3.2 For example, in some states, a corporation can issue shares in exchange for anything of value, including money, property, or services rendered or to be rendered.
cards.frontPrompt: How can different classes of corporate shares vary in rights, what is the board’s role in corporate distributions, and what may constitute valid consideration for issuing shares?

cards.easyContent: Different classes of corporate shares can carry different voting, dividend, and distribution preferences as defined in the articles. The board alone decides whether to declare distributions, and shareholders generally cannot demand them; shares may be issued for any property or benefit of value to the corporation, including money, property, or services.
cards.mediumContent: Share classes may differ in rights, preferences, and limitations as set by the articles, commonly varying in dividend and distribution rights, voting rights, and distribution priority. Corporations may distribute assets through dividends, share redemptions, or liquidating distributions, but at least one class must be entitled to the net assets on dissolution. The board of directors has sole discretion whether to declare a distribution, and shareholders have no general right to compel one. Shares can be issued for valid consideration consisting of any tangible or intangible property or benefit of value to the corporation, such as money, property, or services.
cards.hardContent: Corporations may create multiple classes of shares with distinct rights, preferences, and limitations as specified in the articles of incorporation. Common variations include differing rights to receive dividends or other distributions, different voting rights, and priority in receiving distributions. Corporate distributions of assets may take the form of dividends, redemption of shares, or liquidating distributions upon dissolution, but at least one class must be entitled to the corporation’s net assets when it dissolves. The decision to declare a distribution lies solely within the board of directors’ discretion, even if the articles authorize distributions, and shareholders generally cannot demand them. When issuing shares, the corporation may accept as consideration any tangible or intangible property or benefit of value to the corporation, including cash, other property, or services rendered or to be rendered, depending on state law.

cards.subject: Corporations
cards.rawHeader: Corporations 010. Shareholder Authority and Inspection Rights
cards.backPlain: Shareholders influence and monitor the corporation through two main mechanisms: 1. Governance authority: shareholders exert control over the corporation by electing and removing directors, adopting, amending, or repealing bylaws, and approving fundamental changes to the corporate structure (such as mergers, sales of assets outside the ordinary course of business, and dissolution). 2. Inspection rights: shareholders have statutory rights to inspect the corporation's books and records. They may inspect for any proper purpose—one reasonably related to their interest as shareholders—upon timely written notice stating that purpose, and they may inspect certain core records (such as the articles, bylaws, key reports, and shareholder communications) even without showing a proper purpose.
cards.frontPrompt: How do shareholders exercise governance authority over a corporation, and in general what rights do they have to inspect corporate records?
cards.cloze: Shareholders influence and monitor the corporation through two main mechanisms: 1. {{c1::Governance authority}}: shareholders exert control over the corporation by {{c2::electing and removing directors}}, {{c3::adopting, amending, or repealing bylaws}}, and {{c4::approving fundamental changes}} to the corporate structure (such as {{c5::mergers}}, {{c6::sales of assets outside the ordinary course of business}}, and {{c7::dissolution}}). 2. {{c8::Inspection rights}}: shareholders have statutory rights to inspect the corporation's books and records. They may inspect for any {{c9::proper purpose}}—one {{c10::reasonably related to their interest as shareholders}}—upon timely written notice stating that purpose, and they may inspect certain {{c11::core records}} even without showing a proper purpose.
cards.easyContent: Shareholders control the corporation by electing and removing directors, changing bylaws, and approving fundamental changes, and they also have statutory rights to inspect corporate records (subject to proper-purpose and notice requirements, with some core documents always available).
cards.mediumContent: Shareholders exercise governance authority by electing and removing directors, adopting, amending, or repealing bylaws, and approving fundamental changes such as mergers, sales of substantially all assets outside the ordinary course, and dissolution. Separately, they have inspection rights: they can inspect books and records for any proper purpose—one reasonably related to their interests as shareholders—upon written notice stating that purpose, and they can always inspect key core documents like the articles, bylaws, important reports and minutes, certain board resolutions, and corporate communications to shareholders.
cards.hardContent: Shareholders influence the corporation through governance powers and information rights. Governance authority includes the power to elect and remove directors, adopt, amend, or repeal bylaws, and approve fundamental structural changes such as mergers, sales of assets outside the ordinary course of business, and dissolution. Inspection rights allow shareholders to inspect the corporation’s books and records for any proper purpose—defined as a purpose reasonably related to their interest as shareholders—upon written notice stating that purpose within the required time frame. In addition, shareholders may inspect certain core documents, including foundational documents, key reports, minutes, certain board resolutions, and corporate communications, even without demonstrating a proper purpose.
cards.mnemonic: E-B-F-I: Elect, Bylaws, Fundamental changes, Inspection rights.
cards.atomizationNotes: Split into (1) shareholder governance authority (elect/remove directors, bylaws, fundamental changes) and (2) shareholder inspection rights (proper purpose, notice, and records always available).
cards.clozeLite: Shareholders govern by {{c1::electing and removing directors}}, {{c2::controlling bylaws}}, and {{c3::approving fundamental changes}} and may {{c4::inspect books and records for any proper purpose}}.

cards.subject: Corporations
cards.rawHeader: Corporations 011. Shareholder Meetings and Voting
cards.backPlain: Shareholder governance is exercised through meetings, voting rules, and proxy voting. 1. Meetings: - Corporations must hold annual shareholder meetings to elect directors and conduct other shareholder business, and may call special meetings when matters requiring shareholder approval arise. - Notice of any shareholder meeting must be sent to shareholders eligible to vote. 2. Voting: - Unless the articles of incorporation provide otherwise, each issued share is entitled to one vote. - A quorum of shares must be present (in person or by proxy) for votes to be valid. - Within each voting group, actions are approved if votes cast in favor exceed votes cast against. - Directors are generally elected by plurality, and cumulative voting may be used if authorized in the articles. 3. Proxies: - Shareholders may vote by written proxy. - Proxy appointments are generally revocable, but can be irrevocable if coupled with an interest and clearly stated to be irrevocable.
cards.frontPrompt: How are shareholder decisions made through meetings, voting rules, and proxy voting in a corporation?
cards.cloze: Shareholder governance is exercised through {{c1::meetings}}, {{c2::voting rules}}, and {{c3::proxy voting}}. 1. Meetings: - Corporations must hold {{c4::annual shareholder meetings}} to elect directors and conduct other shareholder business, and may call {{c5::special meetings}} when matters requiring {{c6::shareholder approval}} arise. - {{c7::Notice}} of any shareholder meeting must be sent to shareholders eligible to vote. 2. Voting: - Unless the {{c8::articles of incorporation}} provide otherwise, each issued share is entitled to {{c9::one vote}}. - A {{c10::quorum}} of shares must be present (in person or by proxy) for votes to be valid. - Within each voting group, actions are approved if votes cast {{c11::in favor exceed those cast against}}. - Directors are generally elected by {{c12::plurality}}, and {{c13::cumulative voting}} may be used if authorized in the articles. 3. Proxies: - Shareholders may vote by {{c14::written proxy}}. - Proxy appointments are generally {{c15::revocable}}, but can be {{c16::irrevocable}} if {{c17::coupled with an interest}} and clearly stated to be irrevocable.
cards.easyContent: Shareholder decisions are made at annual or special meetings (with notice to voting shareholders), using default one share/one vote rules with quorum and majority-of-votes-cast approval, directors elected by plurality (with optional cumulative voting), and votes that may be cast personally or by generally revocable written proxies.
cards.mediumContent: Shareholders act at annual meetings—required for electing directors—and at special meetings for matters requiring shareholder approval, with notice sent to all shareholders eligible to vote. Unless altered by the articles of incorporation, each issued share has one vote. A quorum must be present (in person or by proxy), and an action passes within a voting group if votes in favor exceed votes against. Directors are elected by plurality vote, and cumulative voting is allowed if the articles authorize it, letting each share cast as many votes as there are board vacancies and concentrate those votes on one seat. Shareholders can vote by written proxy; proxies are generally revocable, but may be irrevocable if coupled with an interest and clearly state that they are irrevocable.
cards.hardContent: Shareholder governance rests on three pillars: meetings, voting rules, and proxies. Corporations must hold annual shareholder meetings to elect directors and conduct other shareholder business, and may call special meetings when matters requiring shareholder approval arise. Notice of any meeting must be sent to shareholders eligible to vote. Unless modified by the articles of incorporation, each issued share is entitled to one vote. A quorum of shares must be present, either in person or by proxy, for any vote to be valid. Within each voting group, an action is approved if votes cast in favor exceed votes cast against. Directors are elected by plurality (those with the most votes win, even without a majority), and cumulative voting may be used if authorized in the articles, giving each share as many votes as there are board vacancies and allowing shareholders to concentrate multiple votes on a single seat. Shareholders may vote by written proxy that authorizes another person to cast their vote. A proxy appointment is generally revocable, but becomes irrevocable if it is coupled with an interest (e.g., a pledgee or purchaser) and clearly states that it is irrevocable.
cards.mnemonic: Q-PIC: Quorum, Plurality, Individual share vote, Cumulative if allowed.
cards.atomizationNotes: Split into: (1) meetings and notice; (2) voting rules (quorum, approval standard, elections, cumulative voting); and (3) proxies and revocability.
cards.clozeLite: Shareholders act at {{c1::annual and special meetings}} with {{c2::one share, one vote}}; need a {{c3::quorum}}, actions pass if {{c4::votes for exceed votes against}}, and directors are elected by {{c5::plurality vote}}.

cards.subject: Corporations
cards.rawHeader: Corporations 012. Shareholder Lawsuits
cards.backPlain: Shareholders may bring suit against the corporation either directly or through a derivative action to enforce the corporation's rights. 1. Direct suit: a direct suit is brought where the corporation, an officer, or a director caused harm to, or breached a duty owed to, a particular shareholder or a class of shareholders. The recovery is for the benefit of the shareholder or shareholder class. Note: if the duty breached is owed to the corporation, as opposed to an individual shareholder, the proper avenue is a derivative suit. 2. Derivative suit: in a derivative suit, a shareholder sues to enforce the corporation's rights when the corporation has a cause of action but fails to pursue it (i.e., the suit is brought by a shareholder, on behalf of the corporation, usually against officers or directors). This often arises where a director or officer breaches a duty owed to the corporation, but the corporation has not taken action. 2.1 Standing: the shareholder bringing suit must have been a shareholder at the time of the alleged wrong (and often must continue to be a shareholder throughout the litigation). 2.2 Recovery: any recovery goes to the corporation, but shareholders may recoup reasonable legal expenses. 2.3 Written demand required: the shareholder must make a written demand on the corporation and wait 90 days before filing suit, unless: 2.3.1 the corporation has already rejected the shareholder's demand; or 2.3.2 irreparable injury to the corporation will result by waiting the full 90 days. Note: derivative suits often arise as essay questions that present a wrong committed by an officer or director and ask you to identify whether a breach has occurred and what shareholder remedies are available.
cards.frontPrompt: What is the difference between a direct and a derivative shareholder suit, and what are the key requirements for bringing a derivative action?

The recovery is for the benefit of the {{c5::shareholder or shareholder class}}. Note: if the duty breached is owed to the {{c6::corporation}}, as opposed to an individual shareholder, the proper avenue is a {{c7::derivative suit}}. 2. {{c8::Derivative suit}}: in a derivative suit, a shareholder sues to {{c9::enforce the corporation's rights}} when the corporation has a cause of action but fails to pursue it (i.e., the suit is brought by a shareholder, on behalf of the corporation, usually against officers or directors). This often arises where a director or officer {{c10::breaches a duty owed to the corporation}} and the corporation has not taken action. 2.1 {{c11::Standing}}: the shareholder bringing suit must have been a shareholder at the time of the alleged wrong (and often must continue to be a shareholder throughout the litigation). 2.2 {{c12::Recovery}}: any recovery goes to the {{c13::corporation}}, but shareholders may recoup reasonable {{c14::legal expenses}}. 2.3 {{c15::Written demand}} required: the shareholder must make a written demand on the corporation and {{c16::wait 90 days}} before filing suit, unless: 2.3.1 the corporation has already {{c17::rejected}} the shareholder's demand; or 2.3.2 {{c18::irreparable injury}} to the corporation will result by waiting the full 90 days.
cards.easyContent: Shareholders can sue directly for harms to them personally or derivatively on behalf of the corporation when the corporation is harmed and fails to act. Derivative suits require shareholder standing, usually a written demand on the corporation, and any recovery goes to the corporation.
cards.mediumContent: A direct shareholder suit is appropriate when the corporation, an officer, or a director harms or breaches a duty owed to a specific shareholder or class of shareholders, and the recovery goes to that shareholder or class. A derivative suit is brought by a shareholder on behalf of the corporation to enforce the corporation’s rights, typically when officers or directors breach duties owed to the corporation and it fails to sue. For a derivative suit, the plaintiff must have been a shareholder at the time of the wrong (and usually continuously thereafter), must generally make a written demand on the corporation and wait 90 days before filing, and any recovery belongs to the corporation, with shareholders able to recover reasonable legal fees. The demand requirement is excused if the demand is rejected or waiting would cause irreparable harm to the corporation.
cards.hardContent: Shareholders may sue either directly or derivatively. A direct suit is proper when the corporation, an officer, or a director has caused harm to, or breached a duty owed specifically to, an individual shareholder or a defined class of shareholders; the recovery runs to the injured shareholder or class. If the alleged breach is of a duty owed to the corporation, the claim must be brought as a derivative suit. In a derivative action, a shareholder sues to enforce the corporation’s rights when the corporation has a cause of action, often based on a breach of fiduciary duty by officers or directors, but fails to pursue it. The shareholder must have standing—typically ownership of shares at the time of the alleged wrong (and continuous ownership during the litigation). Any recovery belongs to the corporation, though the shareholder-plaintiff may recover reasonable litigation expenses. Before filing, the shareholder must make a written demand on the corporation and generally wait 90 days, unless the corporation has already rejected the demand or waiting would result in irreparable injury to the corporation.
cards.mnemonic: WHO HURT WHO? Shareholder hurt = direct; corporation hurt = derivative.
cards.clozeLite: A {{c1::direct}} suit enforces a duty owed to {{c2::specific shareholders}}, and recovery goes to {{c3::them}}. A {{c4::derivative}} suit enforces {{c5::the corporation’s rights}}.

cards.subject: Corporations
cards.rawHeader: Corporations 013. Directors' Responsibility and Authority
cards.backPlain: The corporation’s board of directors (BoD) has primary responsibility for corporate affairs and overall management. The board’s structure and authority can be understood in four main areas: 1. Composition and selection: The number of directors is set by the articles or bylaws (with at least one director), directors are elected by shareholders, and shareholders may remove directors (subject to any for-cause limitations in the articles). 2. Board procedures: The BoD acts collectively, typically through regular or special meetings that satisfy notice and quorum requirements, or by unanimous written consent without a meeting. 3. Delegation and committees: The BoD generally does not manage day-to-day operations, instead delegating to officers and executives and using director committees, which may oversee corporate affairs but cannot make major decisions reserved to the full board. 4. Fiduciary duties: Directors owe the corporation fiduciary duties of care and loyalty in carrying out their management responsibilities.
cards.frontPrompt: What are the main structural, procedural, delegation, and fiduciary features of a corporation’s board of directors?
cards.cloze: The corporation’s {{c1::board of directors (BoD)}} has primary responsibility for {{c2::corporate affairs and overall management}}. Its powers and responsibilities can be grouped into four main areas: 1. {{c3::Composition and selection}} (number, election, and removal of directors). 2. {{c4::Board procedures}} (meetings, notice, quorum, and action without a meeting). 3. {{c5::Delegation and committees}} (officers, executives, and limits on committee power). 4. {{c6::Fiduciary duties}} (duties of care and loyalty owed to the corporation.
cards.easyContent: The board of directors manages the corporation at a high level: shareholders choose and can remove directors, the board acts through formal meetings or unanimous written consent, delegates daily operations to officers and committees (within limits), and directors owe fiduciary duties of care and loyalty.
cards.mediumContent: The board of directors is the corporation’s central management body. Its structure is defined by the articles or bylaws, which set the number of directors (at least one). Directors are elected and generally removable by shareholders, subject to any for-cause-only removal provisions. The board acts collectively through meetings that must satisfy notice and quorum rules, or by unanimous written consent in lieu of a meeting. The board typically delegates day-to-day operations to officers and may form director-only committees to oversee corporate affairs, though major decisions must be made by the full board. Directors owe fiduciary duties of care and loyalty to the corporation when exercising their authority.
cards.hardContent: The corporation’s board of directors (BoD) is the primary decision-making body for corporate affairs and overall management. The number of directors is fixed or ranged in the articles or bylaws, but there must be at least one director. Directors are elected by shareholders and may be removed by shareholders, usually with or without cause unless the articles limit removal to for cause. The board acts collectively, ordinarily through regular or special meetings that comply with notice and quorum requirements, but it may also act without a meeting by unanimous written consent. Although the BoD is ultimately responsible for corporate policy and oversight, it generally does not manage day-to-day operations; instead, it delegates operational authority to officers and executives and may establish committees of directors to handle particular aspects of corporate affairs, subject to legal and governance limits on committee powers. In exercising their authority, directors owe the corporation fiduciary duties of care and loyalty.
cards.mnemonic: Board basics: "N-E-R-M-Q-C-D" — Number, Election, Removal, Meetings, Quorum, Committees, Duties (care and loyalty).
cards.atomizationNotes: Split into four child cards: (1) board composition, election, and removal; (2) board meetings, notice, quorum, and action without meeting; (3) delegation to officers and committees and committee limits; and (4) directors’ fiduciary duties.
cards.clozeLite: The {{c1::board of directors}} is the corporation’s {{c2::central management body}}, elected and removable by {{c3::shareholders}}, acting via {{c4::meetings or unanimous written consent}} and owing {{c5::duties of care and loyalty}}.

cards.subject: Corporations
cards.topic: Duty of Care and Business Judgment Rule
cards.rawHeader: Corporations 014. Duty of Care and Business Judgment Rule
cards.front: Duty of Care and Business Judgment Rule
cards.backPlain: 1. Directors and officers owe the corporation a fiduciary duty of care. In determining whether that duty was breached, courts apply the Business Judgment Rule. A director or officer act that fails to pass scrutiny under the Business Judgment Rule will be deemed a breach of the duty of care. 2. Business Judgment Rule: courts will not second-guess a poor or erroneous decision made by a director or officer if the decision was made: 2.1 in good faith; 2.2 with the care that an ordinarily prudent person in a like position would exercise under similar circumstances; and 2.3 in a manner the director or officer reasonably believed to be in the best interests of the corporation. 3. Liability for breach of duty of care: if a director or officer breaches the duty of care, they can be held personally liable for damages. 3.1 Limiting liability: the articles can limit directors' and officers' personal liability for monetary damages for breaches of the duty of care. 3.2 Exceptions: the articles cannot limit director or officer liability for: 3.2.1 Intentional violations of law. 3.2.2 Unlawful corporate distributions. 3.2.3 Receiving unentitled financial benefits. 3.2.4 Intentionally inflicted harm on the corporation or its shareholders.
cards.frontPrompt: What is the duty of care owed by directors and officers, how does the Business Judgment Rule operate, and when can liability be limited by the articles?
cards.cloze: 1. Directors and officers owe the corporation a {{c1::fiduciary duty of care}}. In determining whether that duty was breached, courts apply the {{c2::Business Judgment Rule}}. A director or officer act that fails to pass scrutiny under the Business Judgment Rule will be deemed a {{c3::breach of the duty of care}}. 2. {{c4::Business Judgment Rule}}: courts will not second-guess a poor or erroneous decision made by a director or officer if the decision was made: 2.1 in {{c5::good faith}}; 2.2 with the care that an {{c6::ordinarily prudent person in a like position would exercise under similar circumstances}}; and 2.3 in a manner the director or officer {{c7::reasonably believed to be in the best interests of the corporation}}. 3. Liability for breach of duty of care: if a director or officer breaches the duty of care, they can be held {{c8::personally liable for damages}}. 3.1 Limiting liability: the {{c9::articles of incorporation}} can limit directors' and officers' personal liability for {{c10::monetary damages for breaches of the duty of care}}. 3.2 Exceptions: the articles cannot limit director or officer liability for: 3.2.1 {{c11::Intentional violations of law}}. 3.2.2 {{c12::Unlawful corporate distributions}}. 3.2.3 {{c13::Receiving unentitled financial benefits}}. 3.2.4 {{c14::Intentionally inflicted harm on the corporation or its shareholders}}.
cards.easyContent: Directors and officers owe the corporation a fiduciary duty of care, judged under the Business Judgment Rule, which protects good-faith, informed, and reasonably believed best-interest decisions from judicial second-guessing. Articles may limit money damages for duty-of-care breaches but not for intentional misconduct, unlawful distributions, improper benefits, or intentional harm.
cards.mediumContent: The fiduciary duty of care requires directors and officers to act with the care an ordinarily prudent person in a similar position would use under similar circumstances, in good faith and in the corporation’s best interests. Courts apply the Business Judgment Rule, under which they will not second-guess poor or erroneous decisions if made in good faith, with appropriate care, and with a reasonable belief they serve the corporation’s best interests. If the duty of care is breached, directors or officers can be personally liable for damages. The articles of incorporation may limit personal liability for monetary damages for duty-of-care breaches, but cannot eliminate liability for intentional violations of law, unlawful corporate distributions, receipt of improper financial benefits, or intentionally inflicted harm on the corporation or its shareholders.
cards.hardContent: Directors and officers owe the corporation a fiduciary duty of care. To evaluate whether that duty has been breached, courts apply the Business Judgment Rule (BJR). Under the BJR, courts will not second-guess a poor or erroneous business decision if the decision was made in good faith, with the care that an ordinarily prudent person in a like position would exercise under similar circumstances, and in a manner the director or officer reasonably believed to be in the best interests of the corporation. If a director or officer’s conduct fails this standard, the act is treated as a breach of the duty of care and the individual may be held personally liable for resulting damages. The articles of incorporation may limit or eliminate personal liability for monetary damages arising from duty-of-care breaches. However, such provisions cannot limit liability for intentional violations of law, unlawful corporate distributions, receipt of unentitled financial benefits, or intentionally inflicted harm on the corporation or its shareholders.
cards.mnemonic: BJR protects GIR: Good faith, Informed, Reasonable belief.
cards.clozeLite: Duty of care: act as an {{c1::ordinarily prudent person}} in {{c2::good faith}} and in the {{c3::corporation’s best interests}}; protected by the {{c4::Business Judgment Rule}}; articles may {{c5::limit money damages for duty-of-care breaches}}.

cards.subject: Corporations
cards.rawHeader: Corporations 015. Duty of Loyalty
cards.backPlain: Directors and officers owe a duty of loyalty to the corporation, which prohibits them from profiting at the expense of the corporation. This duty commonly arises in: 1. Conflicts of interest: when the fiduciary (or certain related persons) has a personal stake in a transaction involving the corporation. 2. Safe harbors for conflicted transactions: situations in which a conflicted transaction will not result in personal liability (e.g., fairness or approval by disinterested decision-makers after full disclosure). 3. Corporate opportunities: fiduciaries cannot divert to themselves business opportunities in which the corporation has an interest or reasonable expectancy, unless they first offer the opportunity to the corporation.
cards.frontPrompt: What is the corporate duty of loyalty, and what are its main applications (conflicts of interest, safe harbors, and corporate opportunity)?
cards.cloze: Directors and officers owe a {{c1::duty of loyalty}} to the corporation, which prohibits them from {{c2::profiting at the corporation’s expense}}. This duty commonly arises with {{c3::conflicts of interest}}, {{c4::safe-harbor rules for conflicted transactions}}, and {{c5::the corporate opportunity doctrine}}.
cards.easyContent: Directors and officers owe a duty of loyalty that bars them from profiting at the corporation’s expense. It mainly shows up with conflicted transactions (and their safe harbors) and with usurping corporate opportunities.
cards.mediumContent: The duty of loyalty prohibits directors and officers from putting their personal interests ahead of the corporation’s. It commonly arises when they engage in conflicted transactions, which may be cleansed by fairness or approval by fully informed, disinterested decision-makers, and when they attempt to divert corporate opportunities in which the corporation has an interest or reasonable expectancy without first offering them to the corporation.
cards.hardContent: The corporate duty of loyalty forbids directors and officers from profiting at the corporation’s expense. It has three main applications: (1) conflicts of interest—where the fiduciary or certain related persons have a personal interest in a corporate transaction; (2) safe harbors for conflicted transactions—fairness to the corporation or approval by disinterested directors or shareholders after full disclosure can prevent liability; and (3) the corporate opportunity doctrine—fiduciaries may not divert to themselves opportunities in which the corporation has an interest or reasonable expectancy without first offering them to the corporation.
cards.mnemonic: Loyalty: "No Self-Dealing or Stealing Deals"—no conflicts, no stolen opportunities.
cards.atomizationNotes: Split into three children: (1) conflicts of interest and when they exist, (2) safe harbors for conflicted transactions, (3) corporate opportunity doctrine.
cards.clozeLite: The {{c1::duty of loyalty}} bars {{c2::self-interest ahead of the corporation}} in {{c3::conflicted transactions}} and {{c4::corporate opportunities}}.

cards.subject: Corporations
cards.rawHeader: Corporations 016. Mergers
cards.backPlain: A merger is a fundamental corporate change in which two or more corporations combine into a single corporation, often with one absorbing another. Because mergers are fundamental changes, they generally require board and shareholder approval, subject to limited exceptions (such as where the surviving corporation experiences no significant changes). After a merger, the surviving corporation owns all property and assumes all obligations of the constituent corporations. Special rules apply to short-form mergers where a parent owns at least 90% of a subsidiary, and dissenting shareholders typically have appraisal rights to obtain fair market value for their shares if they properly dissent. Subtopics: 1) Definition and approval requirements for mergers. 2) Effects of mergers and short-form mergers. 3) Dissenters’ (appraisal) rights in mergers.
cards.frontPrompt: What is a merger, and what are the main issues to analyze (approval, effects/short-form, and dissenters’ rights)?
