Because mergers are fundamental changes, they generally require {{c4::board and shareholder approval}}, subject to limited exceptions (such as where the {{c5::surviving corporation experiences no significant changes}}). After a merger, the {{c6::surviving corporation owns all property and assumes all obligations}} of the constituent corporations. Special rules apply to {{c7::short-form mergers}} where a parent owns at least {{c8::90%}} of a subsidiary, and {{c9::dissenting shareholders}} typically have {{c10::appraisal rights}} to obtain fair market value for their shares if they properly dissent.
cards.easyContent: A merger is when two or more corporations combine into one. Because it’s a fundamental change, it usually needs board and shareholder approval, changes who owns the property and liabilities, allows short-form mergers when a parent owns 90% of a subsidiary, and triggers dissenters’ appraisal rights.
cards.mediumContent: A merger is a fundamental corporate change where two or more corporations combine into a single corporation, often with one absorbing the others. Mergers usually require board and shareholder approval for each corporation, unless the surviving corporation experiences no significant changes. The surviving corporation ends up owning all property and assuming all obligations of the constituents. Special statutory rules allow short-form mergers when a parent owns at least 90% of a subsidiary, and dissenting shareholders generally have appraisal rights to demand fair market value for their shares if they comply with statutory procedures.
cards.hardContent: A merger is a fundamental corporate transaction in which two or more corporations combine into a single corporation, typically by one surviving corporation absorbing the others. Because mergers are fundamental changes, they ordinarily require both board and shareholder approval, subject to a key exception where the surviving corporation’s articles and shareholders’ rights do not materially change, so its shareholders need not vote. Following a merger, the surviving corporation automatically succeeds to all property and obligations of the constituent corporations. Corporate statutes also authorize short-form mergers when a parent owns at least 90% of a subsidiary’s stock, allowing merger without shareholder approval. Finally, dissenting shareholders are generally entitled to statutory appraisal rights, permitting them, with proper notice and compliance with statutory procedures, to dissent and demand fair market value for their shares instead of participating in the merger.
cards.mnemonic: M&A: Merge corporations, Approvals, Absorption, 90% short-form, Appraisal.
cards.atomizationNotes: Split into three child cards: (1) definition and approval requirements for mergers, (2) effects and short-form mergers, and (3) dissenters’ appraisal rights.
cards.clozeLite: A {{c1::merger}} is a {{c2::fundamental corporate change}} where corporations {{c3::combine into a single corporation}}, requiring {{c4::board and shareholder approval}} and triggering {{c5::short-form and appraisal rights rules}}.

cards.subject: Corporations
cards.rawHeader: Corporations 017. Dissolution and Disposition of Property
cards.backPlain: 1. Dissolution – overview 1.1 Definition and effect: Dissolution terminates the corporation’s legal existence, but the corporation continues to exist solely to wind up and liquidate its affairs; it may not carry on any new or regular business. 1.2 Types of dissolution: - Voluntary dissolution: A fundamental change requiring board and shareholder approval. - Administrative dissolution: Initiated by the state (e.g., failure to file reports or pay fees) and typically curable by the corporation. - Judicial dissolution: Initiated by the attorney general (for abuse of authority, fraud, or illegality) or by shareholders (for serious internal problems like deadlock, abandonment, or waste/misuse of assets). 2. Disposition of property – overview 2.1 A sale, lease, or other disposition of all or substantially all corporate property outside the ordinary course of business is treated as a fundamental change. 2.2 It requires approval by both the board and shareholders, and "all or substantially all" means the corporation is left without significant continuing business activities.
cards.frontPrompt: What are the main types of corporate dissolution and the general rule for when a disposition of assets is treated as a fundamental change requiring board and shareholder approval?
cards.cloze: 1. {{c1::Dissolution}} – overview 1.1 Definition and effect: Dissolution {{c2::terminates the corporation’s legal existence}}, but the corporation continues solely to {{c3::wind up and liquidate its affairs}} and may not carry on {{c4::new or regular business}}. 1.2 Types of dissolution: - {{c5::Voluntary}} dissolution: A {{c6::fundamental change}} requiring {{c7::board and shareholder approval}}. - {{c8::Administrative}} dissolution: Initiated by the {{c9::state}} (e.g., failure to file reports or pay fees) and typically {{c10::curable}}. - {{c11::Judicial}} dissolution: Initiated by the {{c12::attorney general}} (for {{c13::abuse of authority, fraud, or illegality}}) or by {{c14::shareholders}} (for {{c15::deadlock, abandonment, or waste/misuse of assets}}). 2. {{c16::Disposition of property}} – overview 2.1 A sale, lease, or other disposition of {{c17::all or substantially all}} corporate property {{c18::outside the ordinary course of business}} is treated as a {{c19::fundamental change}}. 2.2 It requires approval by both the {{c20::board}} and {{c21::shareholders}}, and "all or substantially all" means the corporation is left without {{c22::significant continuing business activities}}.
cards.easyContent: Dissolution ends corporate existence but the corporation continues only to wind up and liquidate. It can be voluntary, administrative, or judicial. Separately, a sale or other disposition of all or substantially all assets outside the ordinary course of business is a fundamental change requiring board and shareholder approval.
cards.mediumContent: Dissolution terminates a corporation’s legal existence, but the entity continues solely to wind up and liquidate and cannot conduct new or regular business. Voluntary dissolution is a fundamental change needing board and shareholder approval. Administrative dissolution is initiated by the state for failures like not filing reports or paying fees, and can often be cured. Judicial dissolution may be sought by the attorney general for abuse of authority, fraud, or illegality, or by shareholders for deadlock, abandonment, or waste/misuse of corporate assets. Separately, a disposition (sale, lease, or otherwise) of all or substantially all corporate assets outside the ordinary course of business is treated as a fundamental change requiring both board and shareholder approval, and it generally means the corporation is left without significant continuing business activities.
cards.hardContent: Corporate dissolution ends the corporation’s legal existence, but the corporation continues solely to wind up and liquidate its affairs and may not carry on any new or regular business. Dissolution can be voluntary (a fundamental change requiring board and shareholder approval), administrative (initiated by the state for failure to comply with statutory requirements or corporate formalities, and generally curable), or judicial (initiated by the attorney general for abuse of authority, fraud, or illegality, or by shareholders for deadlock threatening irreparable injury, abandonment of business without formal dissolution, or waste or misuse of assets for non-corporate purposes). Separately, a sale, lease, or other disposition of all or substantially all corporate property outside the ordinary course of business is a fundamental change requiring both board and shareholder approval, where "all or substantially all" means the transaction leaves the corporation without significant continuing business activities.
cards.mnemonic: V-A-J: Voluntary, Administrative, Judicial; big asset sales = fundamental change.
cards.atomizationNotes: Split into (1) types, grounds, and effects of dissolution (child -1) and (2) fundamental-change rules for dispositions of all or substantially all corporate assets (child -2).
cards.clozeLite: A {{c1::voluntary dissolution}} is a {{c2::fundamental change}} needing {{c3::board}} and {{c4::shareholder}} approval; likewise a {{c5::disposition of all or substantially all assets}} {{c6::outside the ordinary course}}.

cards.subject: Corporations
cards.rawHeader: Corporations 018. Limited Liability Companies
cards.backPlain: A limited liability company (LLC) is a flexible business entity that combines partnership-style pass-through taxation with corporation-style limited liability. Owners are called members and may also serve as managers. Key points: 1. Formation: LLCs are formed by filing a certificate of formation (or articles of organization) with the state, including basic information such as the LLC’s name, registered office, and registered agent. 2. Operating agreement & governance: The operating agreement functions like corporate bylaws, governing relations among members, rights and duties of members and managers, management structure, voting and distribution rules, and amendment procedures. 3. Management, voting, and distributions: By default, LLCs are member-managed, but they may be manager-managed. Voting and distribution rights are largely contractual and follow the terms of the operating agreement. 4. Duties and good faith: Fiduciary duties of care and loyalty depend on whether the LLC is member-managed or manager-managed, but all members and managers owe an obligation of good faith and fair dealing in performing and enforcing the operating agreement.
cards.frontPrompt: What is an LLC, and what are the main issues to consider regarding its formation, governance, management, and duties?
cards.cloze: A {{c1::limited liability company (LLC)}} is a flexible business entity that combines {{c2::partnership-style pass-through taxation}} with {{c3::corporation-style limited liability}}. Owners are called {{c4::members}} and may also serve as managers. Key points: 1. {{c5::Formation}}: LLCs are formed by filing a {{c6::certificate of formation (or articles of organization)}} with the state, including the LLC’s {{c7::name}}, {{c8::registered office}}, and {{c9::registered agent}}. 2. {{c10::Operating agreement & governance}}: The operating agreement functions like {{c11::corporate bylaws}} and governs member/manager relations, rights and duties, management structure, voting and distribution rules, and amendment procedures. 3. {{c12::Management, voting, and distributions}}: By default, LLCs are {{c13::member-managed}}, but may be {{c14::manager-managed}}; voting and distributions are largely {{c15::contractual under the operating agreement}}. 4. {{c16::Duties and good faith}}: Fiduciary duties of {{c17::care and loyalty}} depend on the management structure, but all members and managers owe {{c18::good faith and fair dealing}} in performing and enforcing the operating agreement.
cards.easyContent: An LLC is a business entity combining pass-through taxation with limited liability. It is created by filing formation documents with the state, governed mainly by an operating agreement, and can be member- or manager-managed with duties and good-faith obligations defined largely by contract.
cards.mediumContent: An LLC combines pass-through taxation with limited liability for its owners (members). It is formed by filing a certificate of formation (or articles of organization) with the state that includes the LLC’s name, registered office, and registered agent. Governance is primarily contractual through an operating agreement, which functions like bylaws and sets out member and manager rights and duties, management structure, voting and distribution rules, and amendment procedures. By default, LLCs are member-managed but may be manager-managed, and voting and distributions follow the operating agreement. Fiduciary duties of care and loyalty depend on the management structure, but all members and managers must act in good faith and with fair dealing in performing and enforcing the operating agreement.
cards.hardContent: A limited liability company (LLC) is an entity that provides its owners (members) with limited liability akin to corporate shareholders while typically allowing pass-through taxation like a partnership. It is formed by filing a certificate of formation (or articles of organization) with the state, identifying the LLC’s name, registered office address, and the name and address of its registered agent. The operating agreement is the central governing document, akin to corporate bylaws, and governs relations among members, the rights and duties of members and managers, management structure, voting rules, distribution of profits and losses, and procedures for amendments. By default, an LLC is member-managed, but the operating agreement may establish a manager-managed structure; voting can be equal or tied to ownership interests, and distributions are controlled by the agreement. In a member-managed LLC, all members owe duties of care and loyalty to each other and to the LLC; in a manager-managed LLC, those fiduciary duties run primarily from managers, with non-managing members typically not owing such duties. Regardless of structure, all members and managers must act in good faith and with fair dealing in the performance and enforcement of the operating agreement.
cards.mnemonic: LLC: Limited Liability by Contract (operating agreement) with pass-through taxes.
cards.atomizationNotes: Split into: (1) definition and formation of LLCs, (2) operating agreement, management, voting, and distributions, (3) fiduciary duties and good faith obligations in member-managed vs manager-managed LLCs.
cards.clozeLite: An {{c1::LLC}} combines {{c2::pass-through taxation}} with {{c3::limited liability}} and is governed mainly by an {{c4::operating agreement}}.

cards.subject: Corporations
cards.topic: Pre Incorporation – Promoter: Definition and Role
cards.rawHeader: Corporations 005-1. Pre Incorporation – Promoter: Definition and Role
cards.backPlain: 1. Promoter – definition and role 1.1 A promoter acts on behalf of a not-yet-formed corporation to obtain capital commitments (funding), usually by forming contracts with parties interested in becoming shareholders upon incorporation. 1.2 Promoters may also work on corporate planning and formation and often become incorporators.
cards.frontPrompt: In corporate law, what is a promoter, and what is the promoter’s typical role before incorporation?
cards.cloze: A {{c1::promoter}} acts on behalf of a {{c2::not-yet-formed corporation}} to obtain {{c3::capital commitments (funding)}}, usually by forming {{c4::contracts with parties interested in becoming shareholders upon incorporation}}. Promoters also work on {{c5::corporate planning and formation}} and often become {{c6::incorporators}}.
cards.easyContent: A promoter is someone who, before incorporation, acts for the future corporation by lining up funding and planning the business, often becoming an incorporator.
cards.mediumContent: A promoter is a person who, before a corporation exists, acts on its behalf to obtain capital commitments and make arrangements for formation. Promoters commonly enter into contracts with prospective investors who will become shareholders upon incorporation and often handle corporate planning and organizational details, frequently becoming incorporators.
cards.hardContent: A promoter is an individual who, prior to a corporation’s formation, undertakes to form the corporation and secure the capital and arrangements needed for it to begin operations. Acting on behalf of the not-yet-formed entity, the promoter typically enters into contracts with prospective shareholders or other parties to obtain funding and other commitments. Promoters also handle corporate planning and formation tasks—such as choosing the state of incorporation, arranging initial governance, and preparing organizational documents—and often serve as incorporators when the corporation is formally created.
cards.mnemonic: PROMOTER PREPS: Plans, Raises capital, May become incorporator.
cards.clozeLite: A {{c1::promoter}} is a person who, {{c2::before a corporation exists}}, {{c3::acts on its behalf}} to {{c4::obtain capital commitments}} and {{c5::arrange formation details}}.

cards.subject: Corporations
cards.topic: Pre Incorporation – Promoter Liability and Exceptions
cards.rawHeader: Corporations 005-2. Pre Incorporation – Promoter Liability and Exceptions
cards.backPlain: 1. Promoter liability on pre-incorporation contracts 1.1 Default rule: The promoter is personally liable for contracts he enters into on behalf of the not-yet-formed corporation. 1.2 The promoter remains personally liable even after the corporation is formed, unless there is a valid novation. 2. Exceptions and related doctrines 2.1 Novation: A novation is an agreement among the promoter, the third party, and the corporation under which the third party releases the promoter and substitutes the corporation as the obligor. 2.2 Indemnification: Even if the promoter remains liable, the corporation may agree to indemnify the promoter if the promoter is held liable on the contract after formation.
cards.frontPrompt: What is the default rule regarding promoter liability on pre-incorporation contracts, and how can novation and indemnification affect that liability after incorporation?
cards.cloze: The {{c1::default rule}} is that the {{c2::promoter is personally liable}} for contracts he enters into on behalf of a {{c3::not-yet-formed corporation}}. The promoter {{c4::remains personally liable even after incorporation}} unless there is a valid {{c5::novation}}. A {{c5::novation}} is an agreement among the {{c6::promoter}}, the {{c7::third party}}, and the {{c8::corporation}} under which the third party {{c9::releases the promoter and substitutes the corporation as the obligor}}. Separately, the corporation may agree to {{c10::indemnify the promoter}} if he is held liable on the contract after formation, but indemnification {{c11::does not itself release the promoter}} from personal liability to the third party.
cards.easyContent: By default, a promoter is personally liable on pre-incorporation contracts and stays liable even after the corporation forms. Only a novation—an agreement among all three parties—releases the promoter. The corporation can also agree to indemnify the promoter if he is sued, but that doesn’t itself cut off his liability to the third party.
cards.mediumContent: A promoter who enters into contracts on behalf of a not-yet-formed corporation is personally liable on those contracts. Incorporation does not by itself end this liability; the promoter remains liable unless the parties enter into a novation, in which the third party releases the promoter and substitutes the corporation as the obligor. In addition, the corporation may agree to indemnify the promoter for any liability he incurs on the contract after formation, shifting the economic burden to the corporation but not eliminating the promoter’s direct liability to the third party absent novation.
cards.hardContent: Promoters are personally liable on contracts they make on behalf of a corporation that does not yet exist because there is no existing corporate principal to bind. This personal liability continues even after the corporation is formed. The only way to cut off the promoter’s liability to the third party is through a novation: an explicit agreement among the promoter, the third party, and the newly formed corporation in which the third party releases the promoter and substitutes the corporation as the party obligated on the contract. Separately, the corporation may agree to indemnify the promoter if he is held liable on the contract, meaning the corporation will reimburse the promoter for losses or judgments, but such indemnification does not itself alter the promoter’s status as an obligor to the third party unless coupled with a novation.
cards.mnemonic: PAL: Promoter personally liable; Adoption adds corp; only Novation cuts liability.
cards.clozeLite: A {{c1::promoter}} is {{c2::personally liable}} on {{c3::pre-incorporation contracts}} and is released only by {{c4::novation}}, while {{c5::indemnification}} just reimburses him.

cards.subject: Corporations
cards.topic: Pre Incorporation – Corporate Liability and Adoption
cards.rawHeader: Corporations 005-3. Pre Incorporation – Corporate Liability and Adoption
cards.front: Corporate Liability on Pre-Incorporation Contracts and Adoption
cards.backPlain: 1. Corporate liability on pre-incorporation contracts 1.1 General rule: The corporation generally has no liability based on pre-incorporation contracts entered into by promoters because the corporation did not yet exist when the contracts were made. 1.2 Exception – adoption 1.2.1 Express adoption: The corporation becomes liable if it expressly adopts the contract, such as by board resolution or other formal corporate action. 1.2.2 Implied adoption: The corporation also becomes liable if it impliedly adopts the contract by accepting or retaining the benefits of the contract with knowledge of its terms. 1.3 Effect of adoption 1.3.1 Adoption makes the corporation liable on the contract going forward, but it does not, by itself, release the promoter from personal liability; a separate novation is needed to cut off the promoter’s liability.
cards.frontPrompt: Before incorporation, does the corporation have any liability on contracts made by promoters, and how can adoption change that? What is the effect of adoption on the promoter’s liability?
cards.cloze: As a {{c1::general rule}}, the {{c2::corporation has no liability}} on {{c3::pre-incorporation contracts}} entered into by promoters, because it {{c4::did not exist}} when the contracts were made. The corporation becomes liable if it {{c5::adopts}} the contract: - {{c6::Express adoption}} occurs when the corporation formally approves the contract, such as by {{c7::board resolution}}. - {{c8::Implied adoption}} occurs when the corporation {{c9::accepts or retains the benefits}} of the contract with knowledge of its terms. {{c10::Adoption}} makes the {{c11::corporation liable}} on the contract, but it {{c12::does not by itself release the promoter}} from personal liability; a {{c13::novation}} is still required to cut off promoter liability.
cards.easyContent: A corporation is not liable on contracts made by promoters before it exists. It becomes liable only if it adopts the contract, either expressly (e.g., by board approval) or impliedly (by accepting the benefits). Adoption adds corporate liability but does not automatically release the promoter; that takes a separate novation.
cards.mediumContent: Because a corporation does not exist before incorporation, it is not bound by contracts that promoters make on its behalf unless it later chooses to adopt them. Adoption can be express, through a formal board resolution or similar corporate action, or implied, when the corporation knowingly accepts and retains the benefits of the contract. Once adopted, the corporation becomes liable under the contract, but the promoter remains personally liable to the third party unless a novation is also executed to release him and substitute the corporation as the sole obligor.
cards.hardContent: At common law, a corporation cannot be bound by contracts made before it legally exists, so it has no automatic liability on agreements entered into by promoters. After formation, the corporation may elect to adopt a pre-incorporation contract, thereby becoming liable on its terms. Adoption may be express—such as by a board resolution or official corporate approval—or implied, as when the corporation, with knowledge of the contract, accepts or retains its benefits. Adoption places the corporation in the position of a party to the contract, but it does not retroactively erase the promoter’s obligations. Unless the parties also enter into a novation, the promoter remains personally liable alongside the corporation, giving the third party multiple obligors.
cards.mnemonic: Adoption adds a debtor; novation is needed to drop the promoter.
cards.clozeLite: A corporation is {{c1::not liable}} on pre-incorporation contracts unless it {{c2::adopts}} them; {{c3::adoption}} adds corporate liability but {{c4::does not release the promoter}} without a {{c5::novation}}.

cards.subject: Corporations
cards.rawHeader: Corporations 005-4. Pre Incorporation – Subscription Agreements
cards.backPlain: 1. Subscription agreement – definition 1.1 A subscription agreement is an agreement whereby a person agrees to buy a specified number of shares from a corporation at a given price. 1.2 Subscription agreements often arise in connection with formation or early-stage financing of the corporation.
cards.frontPrompt: What is a subscription agreement in corporate law, and in what context is it typically used?
cards.cloze: A {{c1::subscription agreement}} is an agreement whereby a person agrees to {{c2::buy a specified number of shares}} from a corporation at a {{c3::given price}}. Subscription agreements typically arise in connection with {{c4::formation}} or {{c5::early-stage financing}} of the corporation.
cards.easyContent: A subscription agreement is a contract to buy a set number of shares from a corporation at an agreed price, usually used when the corporation is being formed or raising early capital.
cards.mediumContent: A subscription agreement is a contract between an investor and a corporation under which the investor commits to purchase a specified number of the corporation’s shares at an agreed price. These agreements are commonly used during the corporation’s formation or in early financing rounds to secure capital commitments from future shareholders.
cards.hardContent: A subscription agreement is a pre-arranged share purchase contract in which an investor agrees to buy a specified number of shares from the corporation at a stated price, often on specified terms and conditions. Such agreements are frequently used in the formation phase or in early financing stages to lock in capital commitments and define the rights and obligations of the subscribing shareholder and the corporation with respect to the issuance and purchase of shares.
cards.mnemonic: SUBSCRIBE: Signed Undertaking to Buy Corporate Registered Investment Before Equity forms.
cards.clozeLite: A {{c1::subscription agreement}} is a {{c2::contract}} where an {{c3::investor commits to buy specified shares}} at an {{c4::agreed price}} during {{c5::formation or early financing}}.

cards.subject: Corporations
cards.topic: Ultra Vires Acts – Definition and Consequences
cards.rawHeader: Corporations 006-1. Ultra Vires Acts – Definition and Consequences
cards.front: Ultra Vires Acts – Definition and Consequences
cards.backPlain: 1. Ultra vires acts 1.1 Definition 1.1.1 A corporation takes an ultra vires act when it acts outside of its stated purpose as set forth in the articles of incorporation. 1.2 Consequences of ultra vires acts (three possibilities) 1.2.1 Shareholder suit: Shareholders may sue the corporation to enjoin the ultra vires act. 1.2.2 Corporate suit: The corporation may sue an officer or director responsible for the ultra vires act for resulting damages. 1.2.3 State action: The state may bring an action to dissolve the corporation.
cards.frontPrompt: What is an ultra vires act, and what are the three main consequences or remedies when a corporation engages in such an act?
cards.cloze: 1. {{c1::Ultra vires acts}} 1.1 Definition 1.1.1 A corporation takes an {{c2::ultra vires act}} when it acts {{c3::outside of its stated purpose as set forth in the articles of incorporation}}. 1.2 Consequences of ultra vires acts (three possibilities) 1.2.1 {{c4::Shareholder suit}}: Shareholders may sue the corporation to {{c5::enjoin the ultra vires act}}. 1.2.2 {{c6::Corporate suit}}: The corporation may sue an officer or director responsible for the ultra vires act for resulting {{c7::damages}}. 1.2.3 {{c8::State action}}: The state may bring an action to {{c9::dissolve the corporation}}.
cards.easyContent: An ultra vires act is when a corporation acts outside the purposes stated in its articles. Consequences include: shareholder suits to enjoin the act, corporate suits against responsible officers or directors for damages, and possible state actions to dissolve the corporation.
cards.mediumContent: A corporation engages in an ultra vires act when it acts beyond its stated purpose in the articles of incorporation. The three main consequences are: (1) shareholders can sue to enjoin the ultra vires act, (2) the corporation can sue officers or directors responsible for the ultra vires act to recover resulting damages, and (3) the state can bring an action to dissolve the corporation.
cards.hardContent: An ultra vires act is corporate conduct outside the purposes specified in the articles of incorporation. Modern statutes limit the use of ultra vires, but where applicable, three principal remedies exist: (1) shareholders may seek an injunction to prevent or halt the ultra vires transaction; (2) the corporation may bring an action against the responsible officer or director to recover losses caused by the ultra vires act; and (3) the state, typically through the attorney general, may institute a proceeding to dissolve the corporation for engaging in ultra vires activities.
cards.mnemonic: Ultra vires: S-C-S — Shareholder injunction, Corporate suit, State dissolution.
cards.clozeLite: An {{c1::ultra vires act}} is when a corporation acts beyond its {{c2::stated purpose in the articles}}; remedies include {{c3::shareholder injunction}}, {{c4::corporate suit vs. officers/directors}}, and {{c5::state dissolution}}.

cards.subject: Corporations
cards.topic: De Facto Corporation – Definition and Requirements
cards.rawHeader: Corporations 006-2. De Facto Corporation – Definition and Requirements
cards.front: De Facto Corporation – Definition and Requirements
cards.backPlain: 2. De facto corporation 2.1 Definition 2.1.1 A de facto corporation exists where an entity’s formation fails to strictly comply with incorporation formalities, but it carries on business as a corporation and may still be treated as a properly formed corporation. 2.2 Requirements for de facto corporation 2.2.1 A corporate law exists under which the entity could have become legally incorporated. 2.2.2 There was a good faith effort to comply with the state’s incorporation laws. 2.2.3 The business acted like a corporation (e.g., conducting business in its corporate name).
cards.frontPrompt: When will an entity with defective incorporation be treated as a de facto corporation, and what are the specific requirements?
cards.cloze: 2. {{c1::De facto corporation}} 2.1 Definition 2.1.1 A {{c2::de facto corporation}} exists where an entity’s formation fails to strictly comply with incorporation formalities, but it carries on business as a corporation and may still be {{c3::treated as a properly formed corporation}}. 2.2 Requirements for de facto corporation 2.2.1 A {{c4::corporate law exists}} under which the entity could have become legally incorporated. 2.2.2 There was a {{c5::good faith effort to comply}} with the state’s incorporation laws. 2.2.3 The business {{c6::acted like a corporation}} (e.g., conducting business in its corporate name).
cards.easyContent: A de facto corporation is a defectively formed entity that is still treated as a corporation if there is a valid incorporation statute, a good faith effort to comply, and the business acts like a corporation.
cards.mediumContent: A de facto corporation arises when an entity fails to strictly comply with incorporation formalities but is nonetheless treated as a corporation. The requirements are: (1) a valid corporate law under which it could have incorporated, (2) a good faith attempt to comply with the incorporation requirements, and (3) the business actually acting like a corporation, such as doing business in the corporate name.
cards.hardContent: A de facto corporation protects owners of a defectively formed entity from personal liability as if the corporation had been properly formed. It exists when: (1) there is an existing, valid corporate statute authorizing incorporation, (2) the organizers make a good faith, though ultimately defective, effort to comply with that statute (for example, by preparing and attempting to file articles), and (3) the business proceeds to act in corporate form, such as transacting in the corporate name and holding itself out as a corporation. If these conditions are met, most jurisdictions treat the entity as a corporation against all but the state.
cards.mnemonic: L-G-A: valid Law, Good faith, Acting corporate.
cards.clozeLite: A {{c1::de facto corporation}} requires: (1) a {{c2::valid corporate law}}, (2) a {{c3::good faith attempt to comply}}, and (3) {{c4::acting like a corporation}}.

cards.subject: Corporations
cards.rawHeader: Corporations 006-3. Corporation by Estoppel
cards.backPlain: 3. Corporation by estoppel 3.1 Persons who treat an entity as a corporation are estopped from denying that the entity is a corporation, particularly when attempting to avoid liability.
cards.frontPrompt: What is the doctrine of corporation by estoppel, and when does it apply?
cards.cloze: 3. {{c1::Corporation by estoppel}} 3.1 Persons who {{c2::treat an entity as a corporation}} are {{c3::estopped from denying}} that the entity is a corporation, particularly when attempting to {{c4::avoid liability}}.
cards.easyContent: Corporation by estoppel prevents someone who has treated an entity as a corporation from later denying its corporate status to escape liability.
cards.mediumContent: Under corporation by estoppel, a person who has dealt with an entity as though it were a corporation is estopped from later denying the entity’s corporate status, especially when trying to avoid contractual or other liability arising from that relationship.
cards.hardContent: Corporation by estoppel is an equitable doctrine that protects parties who rely on an entity’s apparent corporate status. If a person has treated or dealt with a business as a corporation—such as by contracting with it under a corporate name—that person is estopped from later asserting that no corporation exists in order to avoid liability. The doctrine typically operates in favor of the entity and its owners against such a party, and often overlaps with but is distinct from the de facto corporation doctrine.
cards.mnemonic: ESTOP: Entity Seen Treated Officially as a Person.
cards.clozeLite: Under {{c1::corporation by estoppel}}, a person who {{c2::deals with an entity as a corporation}} is {{c3::estopped from denying its corporate status}} to {{c4::escape liability}}.

cards.subject: Corporations
cards.rawHeader: Corporations 010-1. Shareholder Governance Authority
cards.frontPrompt: Through what specific powers do shareholders exercise governance authority and control over a corporation?
cards.backPlain: Shareholder governance authority: 1. General concept: Shareholders exert control over the corporation primarily through voting powers, rather than day-to-day management. 2. Key powers: 2.1 Elect and remove directors: Shareholders have the power to elect the board of directors and, subject to statutory and bylaw procedures, remove directors. 2.2 Bylaws: Shareholders can adopt, amend, or repeal bylaws, unless the articles of incorporation grant concurrent or exclusive bylaw authority to the board (depending on the jurisdiction). 2.3 Fundamental changes: Shareholder approval is required for major structural changes to the corporation, including: 2.3.1 Mergers. 2.3.2 Sale of assets outside the ordinary course of business (typically a sale of substantially all corporate assets). 2.3.3 Dissolution (voluntary winding up of the corporation).
cards.cloze: Shareholder governance authority: 1. General concept: Shareholders exert control over the corporation primarily through {{c1::voting powers}}, rather than {{c2::day-to-day management}}. 2. Key powers: 2.1 {{c3::Elect and remove directors}}: Shareholders have the power to {{c4::elect the board of directors}} and, subject to applicable procedures, {{c5::remove directors}}. 2.2 {{c6::Bylaws}}: Shareholders can {{c7::adopt, amend, or repeal bylaws}}, subject to any allocation of bylaw power in the articles of incorporation. 2.3 {{c8::Fundamental changes}}: Shareholder approval is required for major structural changes to the corporation, including: 2.3.1 {{c9::Mergers}}. 2.3.2 {{c10::Sale of assets outside the ordinary course of business}} (typically a sale of substantially all assets). 2.3.3 {{c11::Dissolution}} (voluntary winding up).
cards.easyContent: Shareholders control the corporation at a high level by electing and removing directors, changing bylaws, and approving fundamental structural changes like mergers, major asset sales, and dissolution.
cards.mediumContent: Shareholder governance authority is exercised through voting powers, not management. Shareholders elect and can remove directors, adopt, amend, or repeal bylaws (subject to any limits in the articles), and must approve fundamental changes such as mergers, sales of substantially all assets outside the ordinary course of business, and dissolution.
cards.hardContent: Shareholders’ role in corporate governance is primarily to vote on key matters rather than manage daily operations. This governance authority includes: (1) electing and, under statutory and bylaw procedures, removing directors; (2) adopting, amending, or repealing bylaws, subject to any allocation of bylaw power between shareholders and the board in the articles of incorporation; and (3) approving fundamental changes to the corporate structure, including mergers, sales of assets outside the ordinary course of business (often framed as substantially all corporate assets), and dissolution. These powers provide the main mechanisms by which shareholders exert control over the corporation.
cards.mnemonic: E-B-F: Elect directors, Bylaws, Fundamental changes.

cards.subject: Corporations
cards.rawHeader: Corporations 010-2. Shareholder Inspection Rights
cards.frontPrompt: What are shareholder inspection rights, including the proper-purpose requirement, notice requirements, and records that may be inspected without showing a proper purpose?
cards.backPlain: Shareholder inspection rights: 1. General right: Shareholders may inspect the corporation's books and records for any proper purpose upon written notice. 2. Proper purpose: 2.1 Definition: A purpose is proper if it is reasonably related to the person's interest as a shareholder (e.g., investigating mismanagement, valuing shares). 3. Notice requirements: 3.1 Timing: The shareholder must provide at least five days' written notice to the corporation. 3.2 Content: The notice must state the proper purpose for the inspection. 4. Records available without proper purpose: Certain core records may be inspected regardless of proper purpose, typically including: 4.1 Articles of incorporation and bylaws. 4.2 Annual reports and meeting minutes. 4.3 Board of directors resolutions regarding share classifications. 4.4 Corporate communications to shareholders.
cards.cloze: Shareholder inspection rights: 1. General right: Shareholders may {{c1::inspect the corporation's books and records}} for any {{c2::proper purpose}} upon {{c3::written notice}}. 2. Proper purpose: 2.1 Definition: A purpose is proper if it is {{c4::reasonably related to the person's interest as a shareholder}}. 3. Notice requirements: 3.1 Timing: The shareholder must provide at least {{c5::five days'}} written notice to the corporation. 3.2 Content: The notice must {{c6::state the proper purpose}} for the inspection. 4. Records available without proper purpose: Certain core records may be inspected {{c7::regardless of proper purpose}}, including: 4.1 {{c8::Articles of incorporation and bylaws}}. 4.2 {{c9::Annual reports and meeting minutes}}. 4.3 {{c10::Board of directors resolutions regarding share classifications}}. 4.4 {{c11::Corporate communications to shareholders}}.
cards.easyContent: Shareholders can inspect corporate books and records if they have a proper purpose related to their interests and give at least five days’ written notice stating that purpose; some core documents (like the articles, bylaws, certain reports, and shareholder communications) are always open to inspection without showing a proper purpose.
cards.mediumContent: A shareholder may inspect the corporation’s books and records for any proper purpose—one reasonably related to their interest as a shareholder, such as investigating mismanagement or valuing their shares—by giving at least five days’ written notice that states the proper purpose. However, certain core documents, including the articles and bylaws, annual reports and meeting minutes, board resolutions regarding share classifications, and corporate communications to shareholders, are available for inspection even without a showing of proper purpose.
cards.hardContent: Shareholder inspection rights provide an important information-gathering tool. A shareholder may inspect the corporation’s books and records for any proper purpose upon written notice. A proper purpose is one reasonably related to the person’s interest as a shareholder, such as investigating suspected mismanagement, valuing their shares, or communicating with other shareholders. Statutes commonly require that the shareholder give at least five days’ written notice to the corporation and that the notice state the proper purpose for the inspection. At the same time, corporate law typically grants unconditional access to certain core documents—such as the articles of incorporation and bylaws, annual reports and meeting minutes, board of directors resolutions regarding share classifications, and corporate communications to shareholders—allowing inspection of these records regardless of whether the shareholder can demonstrate a proper purpose.
cards.mnemonic: PROPER-5 CORE: Proper purpose, 5-day notice, core docs free.
cards.clozeLite: A shareholder may inspect {{c1::books and records}} for any {{c2::proper purpose}} with {{c3::five days’ written notice}}, but {{c4::articles, bylaws, key reports, and communications}} are inspectable {{c5::without showing proper purpose}}.

cards.subject: Corporations
cards.topic: Shareholder Meetings – Annual, Special, and Notice
cards.rawHeader: Corporations 011-1. Shareholder Meetings – Annual, Special, and Notice
cards.front: Shareholder Meetings – Annual, Special, and Notice
cards.backPlain: 1. Annual shareholder meetings: - The corporation must hold annual meetings for electing directors and conducting other shareholder business. 2. Special shareholder meetings: - Special meetings may be called to conduct business requiring shareholder approval. 3. Notice of shareholder meetings: - Notice of any shareholder meeting must be sent to shareholders eligible to vote. - Notice must reasonably inform shareholders of the time, place, and purpose (especially for special meetings and fundamental changes, per typical statutes/exams).
cards.frontPrompt: What are the requirements for annual and special shareholder meetings, and what notice must be given to shareholders?
cards.cloze: 1. {{c1::Annual shareholder meetings}}: - The corporation must hold annual meetings for {{c2::electing directors}} and conducting other shareholder business. 2. {{c3::Special shareholder meetings}}: - Special meetings may be called to conduct business requiring {{c4::shareholder approval}}. 3. {{c5::Notice}} of shareholder meetings: - Notice of any shareholder meeting must be sent to shareholders {{c6::eligible to vote}}. - Notice must reasonably inform shareholders of the {{c7::time}}, {{c8::place}}, and {{c9::purpose}} of the meeting (especially for special meetings and fundamental changes).
cards.easyContent: Corporations must hold annual shareholder meetings to elect directors and may call special meetings for matters requiring shareholder approval. Notice of any meeting must be sent to shareholders eligible to vote, telling them when, where, and why the meeting is happening.
cards.mediumContent: Shareholders exercise their rights at meetings. Corporations are required to hold annual shareholder meetings to elect directors and conduct other shareholder business. Special shareholder meetings may be called when business arises that requires shareholder approval. Notice of any shareholder meeting must be sent to all shareholders eligible to vote and must reasonably state the time, place, and purpose of the meeting, especially for special meetings and major corporate actions.
cards.hardContent: Shareholder meetings provide the formal setting for shareholder action. The corporation must hold an annual shareholder meeting to elect directors and address other shareholder business. In addition, special shareholder meetings may be called when a specific matter requiring shareholder approval arises (such as certain mergers, charter amendments, or major asset sales). For any shareholder meeting—annual or special—the corporation must send notice to all shareholders eligible to vote. The notice should reasonably specify the time, place, and purpose of the meeting so shareholders can decide whether and how to participate, with particular emphasis on stating the purpose for special meetings and fundamental transactions.
cards.mnemonic: Meetings need ATP: Annual, Transactions (special), Proper notice.
cards.clozeLite: Corporations must hold {{c1::annual shareholder meetings}} and may call {{c2::special meetings}}; {{c3::notice}} must go to {{c4::all voting shareholders}} stating {{c5::time, place, and purpose}}.

cards.subject: Corporations
cards.topic: Shareholder Voting – Quorum, Approval, Elections, Cumulative Voting
cards.rawHeader: Corporations 011-2. Shareholder Voting – Quorum, Approval, Elections, Cumulative Voting
cards.front: Shareholder Voting – Quorum, Approval, Elections, Cumulative Voting
cards.backPlain: 1. Basic voting rule: - Unless the articles of incorporation provide otherwise, each issued share is entitled to one vote. 2. Quorum requirement: - A quorum of shares must be present (in person or by proxy) for any shareholder vote to be valid. 3. Approval standard for shareholder actions: - Within each voting group, an action is approved if votes cast in favor of the action exceed votes cast opposing the action. 4. Election of directors: - Directors are elected by plurality vote (candidates with the most votes win, even without a majority). 5. Cumulative voting (if authorized by the articles): - Each share may cast as many votes as there are board vacancies to be filled. - A shareholder may allocate all or some of these votes to a single candidate (e.g., if there are five vacancies, each share gets five votes that can be concentrated on one seat).
cards.frontPrompt: What are the default shareholder voting rules, including one share/one vote, quorum, approval standard, director elections, and cumulative voting?
cards.cloze: 1. Basic voting rule: - Unless the {{c1::articles of incorporation}} provide otherwise, each issued share is entitled to {{c2::one vote}}. 2. {{c3::Quorum}} requirement: - A quorum of shares must be present (in person or by proxy) for any shareholder vote to be valid. 3. {{c4::Approval standard}} for shareholder actions: - Within each voting group, an action is approved if votes cast {{c5::in favor}} of the action exceed votes cast {{c6::opposing}} the action. 4. {{c7::Election of directors}}: - Directors are elected by {{c8::plurality}} vote (candidates with the most votes win, even without a majority). 5. {{c9::Cumulative voting}} (if authorized by the articles): - Each share may cast as many votes as there are {{c10::board vacancies}} to be filled. - A shareholder may {{c11::allocate or concentrate}} all or some of these votes on a single candidate (e.g., if there are five vacancies, each share gets five votes).
cards.easyContent: By default, each share gets one vote. A quorum of shares must be present for a vote to count, and an action passes if more votes are cast for it than against it. Directors are elected by plurality, and if the articles allow cumulative voting, each share gets as many votes as there are director seats and can concentrate them on one candidate.
cards.mediumContent: Shareholders vote on corporate matters using a default one share/one vote rule unless the articles alter it. A quorum of shares must be present, either in person or by proxy, for any shareholder vote to be valid. Within each voting group, an action is approved if votes cast in favor exceed votes cast against. Directors are elected by plurality, meaning those with the most votes win even without a majority. If the articles of incorporation authorize cumulative voting, each share gets as many votes as there are board vacancies and the shareholder may allocate or concentrate those votes among candidates, enabling minority shareholders to potentially secure a board seat.
cards.hardContent: Unless the articles of incorporation provide otherwise, each issued share has one vote on matters submitted to shareholders. For any vote to be valid, a quorum of shares must be present at the meeting, either in person or by proxy, consistent with statutory or bylaw thresholds. Within each voting group, a proposed action passes if the number of votes cast in favor exceeds the number of votes cast against—this is a majority of votes cast standard, not necessarily a majority of shares present. Directors are elected using a plurality standard: the candidates receiving the highest number of votes are elected, even if they do not receive a majority of the votes cast. Cumulative voting, if authorized in the articles, modifies director elections by giving each share as many votes as there are director seats to be filled, and permitting shareholders to allocate or concentrate those votes on one or more candidates (for example, five vacancies give each share five votes that can all be cast for a single nominee), enhancing minority representation.
cards.mnemonic: Think "1-Q-MPC": 1 share/1 vote, Quorum, Majority of votes Cast, Plurality, Cumulative if allowed.
cards.clozeLite: Default shareholder voting: {{c1::one share/one vote}}, {{c2::quorum of shares present}}, {{c3::majority of votes cast}} for actions, {{c4::plurality}} for directors, {{c5::cumulative voting if authorized}}.

cards.subject: Corporations
cards.topic: Proxy Voting – Form, Revocability, and Irrevocable Proxies
cards.rawHeader: Corporations 011-3. Proxy Voting – Form, Revocability, and Irrevocable Proxies
cards.front: Proxy Voting – Form, Revocability, and Irrevocable Proxies
cards.backPlain: 1. Use of proxies: - Shareholders can vote their shares via a proxy, allowing another person to cast the vote on their behalf. - The proxy must be executed in writing (or in another valid record form permitted by statute). 2. Revocability of proxies: - A proxy appointment is generally revocable by the shareholder. - Revocation can occur by notice to the corporation, by issuing a later-dated proxy, or by the shareholder attending and voting in person (subject to statute). 3. Irrevocable proxies – exception: - A proxy may be irrevocable if: (a) it is coupled with an interest (e.g., a pledgee, purchaser, creditor, or party to a voting agreement), and (b) it clearly states that it is irrevocable. - Even an "irrevocable" proxy can often terminate according to its terms or when the underlying interest ends.
cards.frontPrompt: How do proxies work in shareholder voting, and when is a proxy irrevocable?
cards.cloze: 1. Use of proxies: - Shareholders can vote their shares via a {{c1::proxy}}, allowing another person to cast the vote on their behalf. - The proxy must be executed in {{c2::writing}} (or another valid record form permitted by statute). 2. {{c3::Revocability}} of proxies: - A proxy appointment is generally {{c4::revocable}} by the shareholder. - Revocation can occur by {{c5::notice to the corporation}}, by issuing a {{c6::later-dated proxy}}, or by the shareholder {{c7::attending and voting in person}} (subject to statute). 3. {{c8::Irrevocable proxies}} – exception: - A proxy may be irrevocable if: (a) it is {{c9::coupled with an interest}} (e.g., a pledgee, purchaser, creditor, or party to a voting agreement), and (b) it {{c10::clearly states that it is irrevocable}}. - Even an "irrevocable" proxy can often terminate according to its {{c11::terms}} or when the {{c12::underlying interest ends}}.
cards.easyContent: Shareholders can let someone else vote their shares by giving a written proxy. Proxies are usually revocable, but become irrevocable if they are coupled with an interest and clearly state that they are irrevocable.
cards.mediumContent: Instead of attending a meeting personally, a shareholder may authorize another person to vote their shares through a written proxy. Proxy appointments are generally revocable; a shareholder can revoke a proxy by giving notice to the corporation, issuing a later-dated proxy, or appearing and voting in person, subject to statutory rules. A proxy can be made irrevocable if it is coupled with an interest—such as a pledgee, purchaser, creditor, or voting agreement—and the proxy document clearly states that it is irrevocable. Even then, the proxy will typically end by its own terms or when the underlying interest ceases.
cards.hardContent: Shareholder votes may be cast through proxies, which are authorizations for another person to vote the shareholder's shares. Proxies must generally be in writing (or in another record form authorized by statute) and delivered to the corporation before the vote. As a default rule, proxy appointments are revocable: the shareholder may revoke by giving notice to the corporation, by executing a later-dated proxy, or by personally attending the meeting and voting, subject to statutory procedures. A key exception is the irrevocable proxy. A proxy may be irrevocable if two conditions are met: (1) the proxy is coupled with an interest—such as where the proxy holder is a pledgee, purchaser, creditor, or party to a voting agreement or other contract—and (2) the proxy instrument clearly states that it is irrevocable. Even an irrevocable proxy is not perpetual; it generally terminates according to its stated duration, by statute, or when the underlying interest ends.
cards.mnemonic: Irrevocable proxy needs IC: Interest + Clear statement.
cards.clozeLite: A proxy is {{c1::generally revocable}}, but becomes {{c2::irrevocable}} only if {{c3::coupled with an interest}} and {{c4::states it is irrevocable}}.

cards.subject: Corporations
cards.topic: Board of Directors – Composition, Election, and Removal
cards.rawHeader: Corporations 013-1. Board of Directors – Composition, Election, and Removal
cards.front: Board of Directors – Composition, Election, and Removal
cards.backPlain: The corporation’s board of directors (BoD) is the central management body. 1. Number of directors - The number of directors is provided for in the articles of incorporation or bylaws. - The number may be stated as a fixed number or as a variable range. - There must be at least one director. 2. Election of directors - Directors are generally elected by the shareholders. - Election usually occurs at the annual shareholder meeting, unless the governing documents provide otherwise. 3. Removal of directors - Shareholders may remove directors with or without cause. - However, the articles of incorporation may limit removal to for-cause only. - Any additional statutory or bylaw requirements for notice and voting must also be observed.
cards.frontPrompt: How are directors selected and removed, and what are the basic requirements for the size of a corporation’s board of directors?
cards.cloze: The corporation’s {{c1::board of directors (BoD)}} serves as the central management body. 1. {{c2::Number of directors}} - Set by the {{c3::articles of incorporation or bylaws}}, which may specify a fixed number or a {{c4::variable range}}. - There must be at least {{c5::one director}}. 2. {{c6::Election of directors}} - Directors are elected by {{c7::shareholders}}. - Election typically occurs at the {{c8::annual shareholder meeting}}. 3. {{c9::Removal of directors}} - Shareholders may remove directors {{c10::with or without cause}}. - The {{c11::articles of incorporation}} may restrict removal to {{c12::for-cause only}}.
cards.easyContent: The articles or bylaws set the number of directors (at least one). Shareholders elect directors, usually at the annual meeting, and can remove them, generally with or without cause unless the articles require cause.
cards.mediumContent: The board of directors is the core management body. The articles or bylaws specify how many directors serve, possibly as a range, but there must be at least one. Directors are elected by shareholders, typically at the annual shareholder meeting. Shareholders may remove directors with or without cause unless the articles of incorporation limit removal to for-cause only, and any statutory or bylaw procedures for notice and voting must be followed.
cards.hardContent: The board of directors (BoD) is the corporation’s central decision-making body. The number of directors is determined by the articles of incorporation or bylaws, which may specify a fixed number or a variable range; in all cases, at least one director is required. Directors are elected by the shareholders, generally at the annual shareholder meeting, in accordance with any voting or classification rules in the governing documents. Shareholders may remove directors with or without cause, but the articles of incorporation may restrict removal to for-cause only or otherwise condition removal, subject to any statutory protections for minority or cumulative voting structures.
cards.mnemonic: Board “NER”: Number, Election, Removal set in governing docs.

cards.clozeLite: The {{c1::articles or bylaws}} set the {{c2::number of directors}} ({{c3::at least one}}). {{c4::Shareholders elect}} and {{c5::may remove}} directors, usually at the annual meeting.

cards.subject: Corporations
cards.topic: Board of Directors – Meetings, Notice, Quorum, and Action Without Meeting
cards.rawHeader: Corporations 013-2. Board of Directors – Meetings, Notice, Quorum, and Action Without Meeting
cards.front: Board of Directors – Meetings, Notice, Quorum, and Action Without Meeting
cards.backPlain: The board of directors (BoD) acts collectively, typically through meetings subject to notice and quorum requirements, or by unanimous written consent. 1. Board meetings - The BoD may hold regular or special meetings. - Meetings may be held in person or by any means by which all participating directors can simultaneously hear one another (e.g., videoconference or telephone conference). 2. Notice of meetings - Regular meetings may generally be held without notice, unless the articles or bylaws require it. - Special meetings generally require notice; commonly at least two days’ notice is required by statute or governing documents. 3. Quorum for board action - The quorum requirement is usually set by the articles of incorporation or bylaws. - If not specified, a quorum consists of a majority of the number of directors of the corporation. - The board may validly act if a quorum is present and the required vote (often a majority of those present) is obtained. 4. Action without a meeting - The BoD may take action without holding a meeting if all directors consent in writing. - The written consent must describe the action taken and be signed or otherwise authenticated by all directors. - Such unanimous written consent has the same effect as a board action taken at a meeting.
cards.frontPrompt: What are the rules governing board of directors’ meetings, including notice, quorum, and when the board can act without holding a meeting?
cards.cloze: The board of directors generally acts {{c1::collectively}} through meetings or unanimous written consent. 1. {{c2::Board meetings}} - May be {{c3::regular or special}}. - May be held in person or by any means allowing all directors to {{c4::simultaneously hear one another}} (e.g., videoconference). 2. {{c5::Notice}} - {{c6::Regular meetings}} may usually be held without notice. - {{c7::Special meetings}} generally require notice, often at least {{c8::two days'}} notice. 3. {{c9::Quorum}} - Usually set by the {{c10::articles or bylaws}}. - If not specified, a quorum is a {{c11::majority of the number of directors}}. 4. {{c12::Action without a meeting}} - The board may act without a meeting if {{c13::all directors provide written consent}}. - The written consent must {{c14::describe the action taken}} and be signed or authenticated by all directors.
cards.easyContent: The board acts at regular or special meetings, which can be in person or via communications where all directors can hear each other. Regular meetings usually don’t need notice; special meetings do. A majority of directors is a quorum unless the documents say otherwise. The board can also act without a meeting if all directors sign written consent describing the action.
cards.mediumContent: The board of directors usually acts through regular or special meetings. Meetings may be held in person or via technology that allows all directors to hear one another simultaneously. Regular meetings generally need no notice unless required by the governing documents; special meetings typically require at least two days’ notice. A quorum for board action is normally a majority of the authorized number of directors, unless the articles or bylaws provide a different rule. Valid board action requires a quorum and the requisite vote at the meeting. Alternatively, the board may act without holding a meeting if all directors consent in writing to the proposed action, and the written consent describes the action and is properly executed by each director.
cards.hardContent: The board of directors (BoD) acts as a collective body. It may hold regular or special meetings, conducted either in person or via any form of communication that permits all participating directors to hear one another simultaneously, such as telephonic or video conference. Regular meetings generally do not require notice unless the articles of incorporation or bylaws specify otherwise, while special meetings usually require advance notice—often at least two days—consistent with statutory or governance requirements. A quorum for board action is typically established by the articles or bylaws; absent such a provision, a quorum consists of a majority of the total number of directors. The board may take valid action if a quorum is present and the requisite vote (often a majority of those present) is obtained. In lieu of a meeting, the BoD may act by unanimous written consent, provided all directors consent in writing to the action, and the consent describes the action taken. This unanimous written consent has the same legal effect as action taken at a duly convened meeting.
cards.mnemonic: Board “MNQA”: Meetings, Notice, Quorum, Action without meeting.
cards.atomizationNotes: Child 2 of 4 from corporations-013: board meetings, notice requirements, quorum, and action without a meeting.
cards.clozeLite: BoD meetings may be {{c1::regular or special}}; {{c2::special meetings require notice}}, and a {{c3::majority of directors is a quorum}}. The BoD may also {{c4::act by unanimous written consent without a meeting}}.

cards.subject: Corporations
cards.topic: Board of Directors – Delegation to Officers and Committees
cards.rawHeader: Corporations 013-3. Board of Directors – Delegation to Officers and Committees
cards.front: Board of Directors – Delegation to Officers and Committees
cards.backPlain: The board of directors (BoD) is ultimately responsible for corporate management but typically does not manage day-to-day operations itself. 1. Delegation to officers and executives - The BoD sets overall policy and strategy for the corporation. - It delegates day-to-day management and operational authority to corporate officers and executives (e.g., CEO, CFO, COO). - Officers act as agents of the corporation within the authority granted by the board and governing documents. 2. Board committees - The BoD may create one or more committees composed of one or more board members. - Committees may be given authority to oversee or manage specific aspects of corporate affairs (e.g., audit committee, compensation committee). 3. Limitations on committee authority - Committees cannot exercise all powers of the full board. - By statute and under many governance documents, committees generally cannot: - Declare dividends or authorize distributions. - Amend the articles of incorporation. - Adopt, amend, or repeal bylaws. - Approve or recommend fundamental corporate changes (e.g., mergers, major asset sales) that require full board or shareholder approval. - Major corporate decisions that the law or governance documents reserve to the full board cannot be delegated to a committee.
cards.frontPrompt: How does the board of directors delegate authority to officers and committees, and what key limits apply to committee powers?
cards.cloze: The board of directors is ultimately responsible for {{c1::corporate management}}, but it usually does not handle {{c2::day-to-day operations}} itself. 1. {{c3::Delegation to officers}} - The board sets {{c4::overall policy and strategy}}. - It delegates daily management to {{c5::corporate officers and executives}} (e.g., CEO, CFO), who act as {{c6::agents of the corporation}} within granted authority. 2. {{c7::Board committees}} - The board may create {{c8::committees}} composed of one or more {{c9::directors}}. - Committees may be empowered to {{c10::oversee specific aspects of corporate affairs}} (e.g., audit or compensation). 3. {{c11::Limits on committee authority}} - Committees cannot make certain {{c12::major corporate decisions}} reserved to the full board. - Typically, committees may not {{c13::declare dividends}}, {{c14::amend the articles}}, {{c15::adopt or amend bylaws}}, or {{c16::approve fundamental changes}} requiring full board or shareholder approval.
cards.easyContent: The board sets overall corporate policy but lets officers run day-to-day operations. The board can also form director committees to handle specific tasks. However, committees cannot take on major board powers like declaring dividends, amending articles or bylaws, or approving fundamental corporate changes reserved to the full board.
cards.mediumContent: Although the board of directors has ultimate responsibility for corporate management, it typically delegates operational authority to corporate officers and executives, who act as the corporation’s agents within the scope of their authority. The board may also create committees composed of directors to oversee specific areas such as audit, compensation, or governance. However, committees face statutory and governance limits: they generally cannot declare dividends, amend the articles of incorporation, adopt or amend bylaws, or approve or recommend fundamental corporate changes that must be considered by the full board or shareholders. Major decisions reserved by law or governing documents to the full board cannot be delegated to a committee.
cards.hardContent: The board of directors (BoD) is charged with overall corporate management and policy-setting but ordinarily delegates day-to-day operations to officers and senior executives (e.g., CEO, CFO, COO), who function as agents of the corporation under board- or bylaw-defined authority. To manage its workload and provide specialized oversight, the BoD may establish committees composed of one or more directors, such as audit, compensation, or governance committees, and vest them with authority over designated aspects of corporate affairs. Nonetheless, committee authority is limited by statute and by the articles and bylaws: committees generally may not declare dividends, authorize certain distributions, amend the articles of incorporation, adopt, amend, or repeal bylaws, approve or recommend mergers or other fundamental transactions, or take other actions expressly reserved to the full board or shareholders. These major decisions must be made or formally approved by the full board.
cards.mnemonic: DOC: Dividends, Organizational docs, Corporate changes stay with board.
cards.atomizationNotes: Child 3 of 4 from corporations-013: delegation of authority to officers and committees; limits on committee powers.
cards.clozeLite: The {{c1::board}} delegates day-to-day operations to {{c2::officers}} and may form {{c3::director committees}}, but committees generally cannot {{c4::declare dividends}}, {{c5::amend articles or bylaws}}, or {{c6::approve fundamental corporate changes}}.

cards.subject: Corporations
cards.topic: Directors’ Fiduciary Duties – Care and Loyalty (Overview)
cards.rawHeader: Corporations 013-4. Directors’ Fiduciary Duties – Care and Loyalty (Overview)
cards.front: Directors’ Fiduciary Duties – Care and Loyalty (Overview)
cards.backPlain: Directors owe the corporation fiduciary duties that constrain how they exercise their management powers. 1. Fiduciary duty of care (overview) - Directors must act with the care that a reasonably prudent person would use in similar circumstances. - They should be adequately informed, exercise reasonable diligence, and make decisions in good faith. - Many jurisdictions apply the business judgment rule, which presumes that directors who act in good faith, on an informed basis, and in the honest belief that their decisions are in the corporation’s best interests are not liable for honest mistakes of judgment. 2. Fiduciary duty of loyalty (overview) - Directors must put the corporation’s interests ahead of their own personal interests. - They must avoid self-dealing and conflicts of interest (e.g., transactions in which the director has a material personal financial interest) unless properly disclosed and approved under applicable conflict-of-interest rules. - Directors may not usurp corporate opportunities that rightfully belong to the corporation, and they must refrain from competing unfairly with the corporation. 3. Beneficiaries of the duties - These duties are owed to the corporation (and indirectly to shareholders). - Breach of these duties may give rise to derivative suits by shareholders on the corporation’s behalf.
cards.frontPrompt: What fiduciary duties do directors owe the corporation, in general terms, and what do the duties of care and loyalty require?
cards.cloze: Directors owe the corporation {{c1::fiduciary duties}} that constrain how they exercise their powers. 1. {{c2::Duty of care}} (overview) - Directors must act with the care of a {{c3::reasonably prudent person}} in similar circumstances. - They should be {{c4::adequately informed}} and act in {{c5::good faith}}. - The {{c6::business judgment rule}} generally protects directors who act in good faith, on an informed basis, and in the honest belief that their decisions are in the corporation’s best interests. 2. {{c7::Duty of loyalty}} (overview) - Directors must put the {{c8::corporation’s interests}} ahead of their own. - They must avoid {{c9::self-dealing}} and {{c10::conflicts of interest}} absent proper disclosure and approval. - They may not {{c11::usurp corporate opportunities}} or {{c12::unfairly compete}} with the corporation. 3. {{c13::Beneficiaries of the duties}} - These duties are owed to the {{c14::corporation}} (and indirectly to {{c15::shareholders}}), and breaches may be pursued via {{c16::derivative suits}}.
cards.easyContent: Directors owe fiduciary duties to the corporation: a duty of care to act with reasonable diligence and in good faith, and a duty of loyalty to put the corporation’s interests first, avoid self-dealing and usurping corporate opportunities, and not unfairly compete with the company.
cards.mediumContent: As fiduciaries, directors owe the corporation duties of care and loyalty. The duty of care requires directors to act with the care a reasonably prudent person would use, to be informed, diligent, and to act in good faith. The business judgment rule generally protects directors from liability for honest, informed decisions made in the corporation’s best interests. The duty of loyalty requires directors to put the corporation’s interests ahead of their own, avoid self-dealing and undisclosed conflicts of interest, and not appropriate corporate opportunities or unfairly compete with the corporation. These duties run to the corporation (and indirectly its shareholders), and violations are typically enforced through shareholder derivative actions.
cards.hardContent: Directors are fiduciaries of the corporation and owe it core duties of care and loyalty. The duty of care obligates directors to act with the care a reasonably prudent person in a like position would exercise under similar circumstances, including being informed about material information, exercising reasonable diligence in oversight, and acting in good faith. The business judgment rule creates a presumption that directors who act in good faith, on an informed basis, and in the honest belief that their actions are in the corporation’s best interests are not liable for mere errors of judgment. The duty of loyalty requires directors to subordinate their personal interests to those of the corporation: they must avoid or properly manage conflicts-of-interest transactions through disclosure and approval, refrain from usurping corporate opportunities, and avoid unfair competition with the corporation. These duties are owed to the corporation itself (and indirectly to shareholders), and breaches may trigger derivative suits seeking remedies on the corporation’s behalf.
cards.mnemonic: Directors must C.A.R.E. and stay LOYAL: Care = informed; Loyalty = no self-dealing.

cards.topic: Duty of Loyalty – Conflicts of Interest (Definition)
cards.rawHeader: Corporations 015-1. Duty of Loyalty – Conflicts of Interest (Definition)
cards.front: Duty of Loyalty – Conflicts of Interest
cards.backPlain: Directors and officers owe a duty of loyalty to the corporation, which prohibits them from profiting at the corporation’s expense. 1. Conflicts of interest – definition 1.1 A conflict of interest exists when an officer or director has a personal interest in a transaction in which the corporation is a party. 1.2 A conflict occurs if the officer or director knows that he or a family member is: 1.2.1 A party to the transaction; or 1.2.2 Has a beneficial financial interest in, or is so closely linked to, the transaction that it could reasonably be expected to influence how the director or officer votes on the transaction; or 1.2.3 Is affiliated with another entity that is a party to the transaction (for example, is an agent or employee of the other entity).
cards.frontPrompt: When does a conflict of interest arise for a corporate director or officer under the duty of loyalty?
cards.cloze: Directors and officers owe a {{c1::duty of loyalty}} to the corporation, which prohibits them from {{c2::profiting at the corporation’s expense}}. 1. {{c3::Conflict of interest – definition}} 1.1 A conflict of interest exists when an officer or director has a {{c4::personal interest in a transaction}} in which the corporation is a party. 1.2 A conflict occurs if the officer or director knows that he or a family member is: 1.2.1 {{c5::A party to the transaction}}; or 1.2.2 Has a {{c6::beneficial financial interest}} in, or is so closely linked to, the transaction that it could reasonably be expected to {{c7::influence how the director or officer votes}} on the transaction; or 1.2.3 Is {{c8::affiliated with another entity that is a party to the transaction}} (for example, is an {{c9::agent or employee}} of the other entity).
cards.easyContent: A conflict of interest exists when a director or officer (or certain relatives) has a personal stake in a corporate transaction, such as being a party, having a financial interest, or being affiliated with the other entity.
cards.mediumContent: A conflict of interest arises when a director or officer has a personal interest in a corporate transaction. This includes situations where the fiduciary or a family member is a party to the deal, has a beneficial financial interest or close link that could reasonably influence their vote, or is affiliated with another entity that is a party to the transaction (for example, as an agent or employee).
cards.hardContent: Under the duty of loyalty, a conflict of interest exists when a director or officer has a personal interest in a transaction involving the corporation. This occurs if the fiduciary knows that he or a family member: (1) is a party to the transaction; (2) has a beneficial financial interest in, or is so closely linked to, the transaction that it could reasonably be expected to influence how he votes on the transaction; or (3) is affiliated with another entity that is a party to the transaction, such as serving as that entity’s agent or employee.
cards.mnemonic: Conflict = party, pocket, or position in the deal.
cards.clozeLite: A conflict of interest arises when a {{c1::director or officer}} has a {{c2::personal interest}} in a {{c3::corporate transaction}}, such as being a {{c4::party, financially interested, or affiliated with the other entity}}.

cards.topic: Duty of Loyalty – Safe Harbors for Conflicted Transactions
cards.rawHeader: Corporations 015-2. Duty of Loyalty – Safe Harbors for Conflicted Transactions
cards.backPlain: A director or officer with a conflict of interest will not be personally liable for the conflicted transaction if a safe harbor applies. 2. Safe harbors – a conflicted officer or director will not be personally liable if the transaction is either: 2.1 Fair to the corporation given the circumstances existing at the time; or 2.2 Approved, after full disclosure of all material facts, by either: 2.2.1 Disinterested shareholders; or 2.2.2 A majority of disinterested board members.
cards.frontPrompt: What safe harbors can protect a conflicted transaction from personal liability under the duty of loyalty?
