Safe harbors – the conflicted transaction is protected if it is either: 2.1 {{c2::Fair to the corporation}} given the circumstances existing at the time; or 2.2 {{c3::Approved}}, after {{c4::full disclosure of all material facts}}, by either: 2.2.1 {{c5::Disinterested shareholders}}; or 2.2.2 A majority of {{c6::disinterested board members}}.
cards.easyContent: A conflicted transaction is protected if it was fair to the corporation, or if fully informed, disinterested directors or shareholders approved it.
cards.mediumContent: Safe harbors for conflicted transactions are: (1) the transaction is fair to the corporation under the circumstances at the time; or (2) after full disclosure of all material facts, the transaction is approved either by disinterested shareholders or by a majority of disinterested directors.
cards.hardContent: Even if a director or officer has a conflict of interest, the transaction will generally not result in personal liability if a safe harbor applies. The main safe harbors are: (1) fairness—the transaction is fair to the corporation given the circumstances existing at the time; or (2) informed approval—after full disclosure of all material facts regarding the conflict and the transaction, it is approved either by disinterested shareholders or by a majority of disinterested board members.

cards.clozeLite: Safe harbors: {{c1::fair to the corporation}} or {{c2::fully informed approval}} by {{c3::disinterested directors}} or {{c4::disinterested shareholders}}.

cards.topic: Duty of Loyalty – Corporate Opportunity Doctrine
cards.rawHeader: Corporations 015-3. Duty of Loyalty – Corporate Opportunity Doctrine
cards.backPlain: Under the corporate opportunity doctrine, fiduciary duties prevent officers and directors from diverting to themselves certain business opportunities that rightfully belong to the corporation. 3. Corporate opportunities 3.1 Fiduciary duties prevent officers and directors from diverting a business opportunity to themselves when: • The corporation would have an interest or reasonable expectancy in the opportunity; and 3.2 The officer or director does not first give the corporation an opportunity to act on the opportunity.
cards.frontPrompt: What is the corporate opportunity doctrine under the duty of loyalty?

cards.easyContent: Directors and officers may not take for themselves business opportunities in which the corporation has an interest or expectancy, unless they first offer the opportunity to the corporation.
cards.mediumContent: The corporate opportunity doctrine bars directors and officers from diverting to themselves business opportunities in which the corporation has an interest or reasonable expectancy, unless they first disclose the opportunity and give the corporation a chance to act on it.
cards.hardContent: Under the corporate opportunity doctrine, directors and officers breach the duty of loyalty if they divert to themselves business opportunities in which the corporation has an interest or reasonable expectancy and they fail to first offer those opportunities to the corporation. They must disclose the opportunity and allow the corporation a chance to act before pursuing it personally.
cards.mnemonic: Don’t steal company deals—offer expected opportunities first.

cards.subject: Corporations
cards.rawHeader: Corporations 016-1. Mergers – Definition and Approval Requirements
cards.backPlain: 1. Definition of a merger: - A merger occurs when two or more corporations combine into a single corporation; often one corporation absorbs another. 2. Mergers as fundamental corporate changes: - A merger is a fundamental corporate change and therefore generally requires formal approval from each constituent corporation. 3. Requirements for approval (each corporation generally must obtain): 3.1 Board approval: - A board vote in accordance with the rules for authorizing board action (for example, a majority or supermajority, as required by statute or the articles/bylaws). 3.2 Shareholder approval: - Approval by a majority of the shareholders entitled to vote (unless a higher vote is required by statute, the articles, or the bylaws). 3.3 Exception – no significant change to surviving corporation: - The surviving corporation’s shareholders need not approve a merger where the surviving corporation has no significant changes, such as: • Its articles of incorporation do not differ post-merger; and • The shareholders’ shares and rights do not change (same class, rights, and preferences).
cards.frontPrompt: What is a corporate merger, and what board and shareholder approvals are generally required, including the key exception for the surviving corporation?

Mergers as fundamental corporate changes: - A merger is a {{c4::fundamental corporate change}} and therefore generally requires formal approval from each constituent corporation. 3. Requirements for approval (each corporation generally must obtain): 3.1 {{c5::Board approval}}: - A board vote in accordance with the rules for authorizing board action (for example, a {{c6::majority or supermajority}} as required). 3.2 {{c7::Shareholder approval}}: - Approval by a {{c8::majority of the shareholders entitled to vote}} (unless a higher vote is required by statute or the articles). 3.3 {{c9::Exception – no significant change to surviving corporation}}: - The surviving corporation’s shareholders {{c10::need not approve}} a merger where the surviving corporation has {{c11::no significant changes}}, such as: • Its {{c12::articles of incorporation}} do not differ post-merger; and • The shareholders’ {{c13::shares and rights do not change}}.
cards.easyContent: A merger is when two or more corporations combine into one. Because it’s a fundamental change, each corporation generally needs (1) board approval by the required board vote and (2) majority shareholder approval, unless the surviving corporation’s articles and shareholder rights do not significantly change, in which case its shareholders don’t have to approve.
cards.mediumContent: A merger occurs when two or more corporations combine into a single corporation, often with one absorbing the others. Mergers are fundamental corporate changes, so each constituent corporation typically must obtain board approval and majority shareholder approval under the applicable voting rules. There is a key exception: if the surviving corporation’s articles and the rights and shares of its shareholders remain substantially unchanged, its shareholders generally need not vote on the merger.
cards.hardContent: A merger is a fundamental corporate transaction in which two or more corporations combine into a single corporation, usually through one surviving corporation absorbing the others. Because mergers are treated as fundamental corporate changes, each constituent corporation generally must secure: (1) board approval, by the level of board vote required to authorize corporate action (often a majority or supermajority); and (2) shareholder approval, typically by a majority of the shares entitled to vote, subject to any higher thresholds imposed by statute or governing documents. An important statutory exception eliminates the need for approval by the surviving corporation’s shareholders when the merger results in no significant changes to the surviving corporation—its articles of incorporation remain effectively the same, and its shareholders retain the same shares and rights—so that from their perspective, nothing materially changes.

cards.subject: Corporations
cards.rawHeader: Corporations 016-2. Mergers – Effects and Short-Form Mergers
cards.backPlain: 1. Effect of merger: - Upon effectiveness of the merger, the surviving corporation: • Owns all property of the constituent corporations; and • Assumes all obligations and liabilities of the constituent corporations. - The constituent corporations (other than the survivor) cease to exist as separate corporate entities. 2. Short-form merger: - A short-form merger is a simplified statutory merger procedure used when a parent corporation owns a very high percentage of a subsidiary. - When a parent corporation owns at least 90% of the stock of a subsidiary: • The subsidiary can be merged into the parent corporation (or sometimes the parent into the subsidiary, depending on statute); • The merger can occur without approval of the shareholders of either corporation (no shareholder vote required for parent or subsidiary), though board approval and notice filings are still governed by statute. - The same basic effects apply: the surviving corporation ends up owning all property and assuming all obligations of the constituent corporations.
cards.frontPrompt: What are the legal effects of a merger on property and liabilities, and what is a short-form merger (including the 90% ownership threshold and shareholder approval rule)?
cards.cloze: 1. {{c1::Effect of merger}}: - Upon effectiveness of the merger, the {{c2::surviving corporation}}: • {{c3::Owns all property}} of the constituent corporations; and • {{c4::Assumes all obligations and liabilities}} of the constituent corporations. - The constituent corporations (other than the survivor) {{c5::cease to exist as separate entities}}. 2. {{c6::Short-form merger}}: - A short-form merger is a simplified statutory merger procedure used when a parent corporation owns a very high percentage of a subsidiary. - When a parent corporation owns at least {{c7::90%}} of the stock of a subsidiary: • The subsidiary can be {{c8::merged into the parent corporation}} (or vice versa, depending on statute); • The merger can occur {{c9::without approval of the shareholders of either corporation}} (no shareholder vote for parent or subsidiary). - The same basic effects apply: the {{c10::surviving corporation owns all property and assumes all obligations}} of the constituent corporations.
cards.easyContent: In a merger, the surviving corporation takes all the property and all the liabilities of the merged corporations, and the other corporations disappear. A short-form merger lets a parent that owns at least 90% of a subsidiary merge it without any shareholder vote for either company; the survivor still ends up with all the assets and liabilities.
cards.mediumContent: The principal legal effect of a merger is that the surviving corporation automatically succeeds to all property and all obligations of the constituent corporations, which cease to exist as separate entities. In a short-form merger, when a parent owns at least 90% of a subsidiary’s stock, statutory law allows the parent to merge the subsidiary into the parent (or vice versa) without any shareholder approval from either corporation. The merger still has the same substantive effect: the surviving entity owns all assets and is liable for all obligations of the merged entities.
cards.hardContent: Once a merger becomes effective under the applicable statute, the surviving corporation steps into the shoes of the constituent corporations: it automatically owns all their property (real, personal, and intangible) and assumes all of their obligations and liabilities, while the other corporations are extinguished as separate legal entities. Many corporate statutes provide a streamlined short-form merger mechanism when a parent corporation holds at least 90% of a subsidiary’s outstanding shares. In such cases, the parent may effect a merger with the subsidiary without seeking approval from the shareholders of either corporation, subject to any statutory notice and filing requirements. Despite the simplified procedure, the core legal consequences remain the same: consolidation of ownership and liabilities in the surviving corporation.
cards.mnemonic: Merger: A+L to survivor; 90% parent = short-cut, no votes.

cards.clozeLite: In a merger, the {{c1::surviving corporation}} takes {{c2::all property and all obligations}} of the {{c3::constituent corporations}}. A {{c4::short-form merger}} lets a {{c5::90%-owner parent}} merge a subsidiary {{c6::without any shareholder approval}}.

cards.subject: Corporations
cards.rawHeader: Corporations 016-3. Mergers – Dissenters’ (Appraisal) Rights
cards.backPlain: 1. Dissenters’ (appraisal) rights – basic concept: - Dissenting shareholders can challenge the merger transaction or, more commonly, demand payment for their shares at fair market value instead of going along with the merger. 2. When appraisal rights arise (in general): - In many jurisdictions, appraisal rights are triggered when a shareholder is entitled to vote on certain fundamental transactions, such as a merger, and opposes the transaction. (Exact triggers vary by statute.) 3. Mutual notice and procedure requirements: 3.1 Corporation’s notice obligations: - Before a vote is taken on the merger, the corporation must give shareholders: • Notice of the shareholders’ meeting at which the merger will be voted on; and • Notice of their appraisal (dissenters’) rights and how to exercise them. 3.2 Shareholders’ obligations to perfect rights: - Shareholders must follow statutory procedures to perfect appraisal rights, which generally include: • Giving timely notice of their intent to dissent; • Not voting in favor of the merger; and • Complying with any additional statutory steps, such as submitting share certificates or written demands. 4. Valuation and payment: 4.1 Corporation’s obligation to pay: - If the merger is approved, the corporation must pay dissenting shareholders the fair market value (FMV) for their shares, as determined under the applicable statute. 4.2 Disputes and judicial determination: - If the shareholder and corporation cannot agree on the FMV, a court (or occasionally an appraiser appointed under statute) will determine the fair value to be paid. 4.3 Nature of the remedy: - Appraisal is typically the shareholder’s exclusive remedy for challenging the price of a merger, absent fraud, illegality, or other serious wrongdoing.
cards.frontPrompt: What are dissenters’ (appraisal) rights in a merger, including notice, perfection procedures, and how fair market value is determined and paid?
cards.cloze: 1. {{c1::Dissenters’ (appraisal) rights}} – basic concept: - Dissenting shareholders can {{c2::challenge the merger transaction or demand payment for their shares at fair market value}} instead of going along with the merger. 2. When appraisal rights arise (in general): - Appraisal rights are typically triggered when a shareholder {{c3::is entitled to vote on a merger or other fundamental transaction}} and {{c4::opposes the transaction}} (exact triggers depend on statute). 3. {{c5::Mutual notice and procedure requirements}}: 3.1 Corporation’s notice obligations: - Before a vote is taken on the merger, the corporation must give shareholders: • {{c6::Notice of the meeting}} at which the merger will be voted on; and • {{c7::Notice of their appraisal rights}} and how to exercise them. 3.2 Shareholders’ obligations to perfect rights: - Shareholders must follow statutory procedures to perfect appraisal rights, generally including: • Giving {{c8::timely notice of intent to dissent}}; • {{c9::Not voting in favor of the merger}}; and • Complying with {{c10::additional statutory steps}} (e.g., submitting share certificates or written demands). 4. {{c11::Valuation and payment}}: 4.1 Corporation’s obligation to pay: - If the merger is approved, the corporation must pay dissenting shareholders the {{c12::fair market value (FMV)}} for their shares, as determined under the applicable statute. 4.2 Disputes and judicial determination: - If the parties cannot agree on FMV, a {{c13::court or statutory appraiser}} will determine the {{c14::fair value}} to be paid. 4.3 Nature of the remedy: - Appraisal is typically the shareholder’s {{c15::exclusive remedy for challenging the price of a merger}}, absent {{c16::fraud, illegality, or other serious wrongdoing}}.
cards.easyContent: Dissenting shareholders in a merger can refuse to go along and instead demand cash for their shares at fair market value. The corporation must notify them of these rights before the vote, and they must follow statutory steps to perfect the rights. If the merger is approved, the corporation pays FMV, and a court decides value if they cannot agree.
cards.mediumContent: Appraisal rights let shareholders who oppose a merger exit the company by receiving cash equal to the fair market value of their shares. The corporation must notify shareholders before the merger vote of both the meeting and the existence of appraisal rights. To perfect the right, shareholders must give timely notice of dissent, refrain from voting in favor of the merger, and comply with statutory procedures. If the merger closes, the corporation is obliged to pay fair market value for the dissenters’ shares; if the parties dispute value, a court (or statutory appraiser) determines the fair value. Absent fraud or illegality, this appraisal remedy is usually the dissenters’ exclusive way to challenge the merger price.
cards.hardContent: Dissenters’ or appraisal rights provide a statutory exit remedy for shareholders who oppose a merger or similar fundamental transaction. When a shareholder is entitled to vote on such a transaction and objects, the corporation must, prior to the vote, give formal notice of the meeting and clearly disclose that appraisal rights are available and how they may be exercised. The shareholder must then strictly comply with statutory perfection requirements—typically including giving written notice of intent to dissent before or at the meeting, abstaining from voting in favor of the merger, and completing any additional steps such as depositing share certificates or making a written demand. If the merger is approved, the corporation must pay dissenting shareholders the fair market value of their shares as of the relevant valuation date. If the parties cannot agree on that value, the statute ordinarily provides for a judicial or appraiser-driven proceeding to determine the fair value. In many jurisdictions, appraisal is the exclusive remedy for challenging the adequacy of the merger consideration, absent fraud, illegality, or other egregious misconduct by those effecting the transaction.
cards.mnemonic: N-P-V: Notice, Perfect right, receive Value.

cards.clozeLite: Appraisal rights let dissenting shareholders {{c1::exit for cash at fair market value}} if they {{c2::give timely notice of dissent}}, {{c3::do not vote for the merger}}, and {{c4::follow statutory perfection procedures}}.

cards.subject: Corporations
cards.rawHeader: Corporations 017-1. Dissolution – Types, Grounds, and Effect
cards.backPlain: 1. Dissolution – definition and effect 1.1 Dissolution terminates the corporation’s legal existence, but the corporation continues to exist solely to wind up and liquidate its affairs. 1.2 After dissolution, the corporation may not carry on any new or regular business; it is limited to winding up activities (e.g., collecting assets, paying debts, distributing remaining assets). 2. Voluntary dissolution 2.1 Nature: Voluntary dissolution is treated as a fundamental corporate change. 2.2 Approval: It requires board approval and approval by the shareholders under the applicable voting rules. 3. Administrative dissolution 3.1 Initiated by the state (usually the secretary of state) to dissolve the corporation. 3.2 Typical grounds: Failure to comply with statutory requirements or corporate formalities, such as failure to file required reports or pay fees. 3.3 Cure: Administrative dissolution is generally curable by the corporation by correcting the default and following statutory reinstatement procedures. 4. Judicial dissolution 4.1 Who can bring the action? - Attorney general. - Shareholders. 4.2 Attorney general’s grounds: - The corporation abused its authority. - The corporation committed fraud. - The corporation acted unlawfully. 4.3 Shareholders’ grounds: - Deadlock among the board of directors or among shareholders that threatens irreparable injury to the corporation. - The corporation has abandoned its business and failed to dissolve. - Corporate assets are being wasted or misused for non-corporate purposes.

cards.easyContent: Dissolution ends a corporation’s legal existence but it continues only to wind up and liquidate, not to conduct new business. Dissolution can be voluntary (a fundamental change needing board and shareholder approval), administrative (state-initiated but usually curable), or judicial (brought by the attorney general for abuse, fraud, or illegality, or by shareholders for deadlock, abandonment, or waste/misuse of assets).
cards.mediumContent: Dissolution terminates the corporation’s legal existence, but it survives solely to wind up and liquidate its affairs and may not carry on new or regular business. Voluntary dissolution is a fundamental corporate change requiring approval by both the board and shareholders. Administrative dissolution is initiated by the state, typically for failure to comply with statutory requirements or corporate formalities, such as not filing reports or paying fees; it can generally be cured by correcting the default and seeking reinstatement. Judicial dissolution can be brought by the attorney general when the corporation abuses its authority, commits fraud, or acts unlawfully, or by shareholders where there is deadlock threatening irreparable injury, abandonment of business without formal dissolution, or waste or misuse of corporate assets for non-corporate purposes.
cards.hardContent: Dissolution is the formal termination of a corporation’s legal existence, but the entity continues solely to wind up and liquidate its affairs—collecting assets, paying creditors, and distributing any remaining assets to shareholders—and may not conduct new or regular business. Voluntary dissolution is treated as a fundamental corporate change and requires board approval and shareholder approval under the applicable voting rules. Administrative dissolution is brought by the state, often the secretary of state, usually because the corporation failed to comply with statutory requirements or corporate formalities, such as failing to file required reports or pay franchise fees; statutes generally allow the corporation to cure these failures and be reinstated. Judicial dissolution may be sought by the attorney general on grounds that the corporation abused its authority, committed fraud, or acted unlawfully. Shareholders may seek judicial dissolution when there is deadlock among directors or shareholders that threatens irreparable injury, when the corporation has abandoned its business but failed to dissolve, or when corporate assets are being wasted or misused for non-corporate purposes.

cards.subject: Corporations
cards.rawHeader: Corporations 017-2. Disposition of Property – Fundamental Change
cards.backPlain: 1. Disposition of property – definition 1.1 A disposition of property includes a sale, lease, or other disposition of corporate property. 2. When a disposition is a fundamental change 2.1 A disposition of all or substantially all of the corporation’s property, outside the regular or ordinary course of business, is treated as a fundamental corporate change. 2.2 "All or substantially all" assets means the transaction leaves the corporation without significant continuing business activities. 2.3 The disposition must be outside the ordinary course of the corporation’s business; large transactions within the ordinary course do not count as fundamental changes. 3. Approval requirements 3.1 Because it is treated as a fundamental change, such a disposition requires: - Approval by the board of directors; and - Approval by the shareholders under the applicable voting rules.
cards.frontPrompt: When is a disposition of corporate property treated as a fundamental change, what does "all or substantially all" mean, and what approvals are required?

Approval requirements 3.1 Because it is a fundamental change, such a disposition requires: - Approval by the {{c8::board of directors}}; and - Approval by the {{c9::shareholders}} under the applicable voting rules.
cards.easyContent: A sale, lease, or other disposition of all or substantially all corporate assets outside the ordinary course of business is a fundamental change. It leaves the corporation without significant continuing business activities and requires both board and shareholder approval.
cards.mediumContent: A disposition of corporate property (by sale, lease, or otherwise) is treated as a fundamental change when it involves all or substantially all of the corporation’s assets and occurs outside the ordinary course of business. "All or substantially all" means the corporation will not have significant continuing business activities after the transaction. Because it is a fundamental change, this kind of disposition requires approval by both the board of directors and the shareholders under the applicable voting rules.
cards.hardContent: A disposition of corporate property, including a sale, lease, or other transfer, is treated as a fundamental change when it involves all or substantially all of the corporation’s assets outside the ordinary course of business. The "all or substantially all" threshold is met when the corporation is left without significant continuing business activities after the transaction. Transactions of any size that are within the ordinary course of the corporation’s business are not treated as fundamental changes. When the disposition qualifies as a fundamental change, it must be approved by the board of directors and by the shareholders under the applicable voting rules before it can be implemented.

Definition 1.1 A limited liability company (LLC) is a business entity that combines partnership-style pass-through taxation with corporation-style limited liability. 1.2 The owners of an LLC are called members, and members may also serve as managers. 2. cards.easyContent: An LLC is a separate business entity that gives its owners (members) limited liability and usually pass-through taxation. It is created by filing a certificate of formation (or articles of organization) with the state, listing the LLC’s name, registered office, and registered agent.
cards.mediumContent: An LLC is a hybrid entity that combines pass-through taxation with limited liability for its owners, called members, who may also act as managers. To form an LLC, the organizers must file a certificate of formation (or articles of organization) with the state, typically identifying the LLC’s name, its registered office address, and the name and address of its registered agent. cards.hardContent: A limited liability company (LLC) is a statutory business entity that offers its owners (members) limited liability protection similar to corporate shareholders while usually allowing partnership-style pass-through taxation. Members may also serve as managers of the business. An LLC is formed by filing a certificate of formation (or articles of organization) with the appropriate state office. The filing must generally set out the LLC’s legal name, the address of its registered office, and the name and address of its registered agent for service of process. Once the filing is properly made and accepted, the LLC exists as a separate legal person that can own property, enter contracts, and sue or be sued in its own name, and that generally shields members from personal liability for the LLC’s debts and liabilities, subject to doctrines such as veil-piercing and specific statutory exceptions.

cards.topic: LLCs – Operating Agreement, Management, Voting, and Distributions
cards.rawHeader: Corporations 018-2. LLCs – Operating Agreement, Management, Voting, and Distributions
cards.front: LLCs – Operating Agreement, Management, Voting, and Distributions
cards.backPlain: 1. Operating agreement 1.1 The operating agreement is the primary governing document of an LLC, similar to corporate bylaws. 1.2 It governs: • Relations among members; • The rights and duties of members and managers; • The management structure (member-managed vs manager-managed); • Voting rights and procedures; • Allocation and distribution of profits and losses; and • Procedures for amending the agreement. 2. Management structure 2.1 Default rule: By default, an LLC is member-managed—each member has authority to participate in management. 2.2 Manager-managed option: The operating agreement may instead provide for one or more managers and non-managing members, creating a manager-managed LLC. 3. Voting 3.1 Voting in a member-managed or manager-managed LLC is determined by the operating agreement. 3.2 Voting may be: • Per capita (equal voting rights for each member or manager); or • Proportionate to ownership interests (votes weighted by percentage interest). 4. Distributions 4.1 The operating agreement generally dictates how profits and losses will be allocated and distributed among members. 4.2 In the absence of a contrary agreement, default statutory rules may allocate distributions per capita or by ownership share, depending on the jurisdiction.
cards.frontPrompt: What role does the operating agreement play in an LLC, and how does it govern management structure, voting rights, and distributions of profits and losses?

cards.easyContent: The operating agreement is the LLC’s main governing contract. It sets who manages (members vs managers), how voting works (equal or by ownership percentage), and how profits and losses are allocated and distributed.
cards.mediumContent: An LLC’s operating agreement functions like corporate bylaws and governs internal affairs, including relations among members, rights and duties of members and managers, management structure, voting rights, distributions, and amendment procedures. By default, LLCs are member-managed, but the operating agreement can create a manager-managed structure. Voting and distributions are primarily contractual: the agreement may allocate votes per capita or by ownership interest, and control how profits and losses are allocated and distributed; otherwise, default statutory rules apply.
cards.hardContent: The operating agreement is the central contractual document governing an LLC’s internal affairs. It operates much like corporate bylaws but with greater contractual flexibility. It defines relations among members, the rights and duties of members and managers, and whether the LLC will be member-managed (the default) or manager-managed (with designated managers and non-managing members). The agreement also sets voting rights and procedures, which may give each member or manager one equal vote (per capita) or weight votes by percentage ownership, and specifies how and when profits and losses are allocated and distributed. The operating agreement further establishes amendment procedures. In the absence of contrary terms, default state statutory provisions control management, voting, and distributions, which often allocate rights either per capita or in proportion to ownership interests.

cards.topic: LLCs – Fiduciary Duties and Good Faith
cards.rawHeader: Corporations 018-3. LLCs – Fiduciary Duties and Good Faith
cards.front: LLCs – Fiduciary Duties and Good Faith
cards.backPlain: 1. Member-managed LLCs 1.1 In a member-managed LLC, all members generally owe fiduciary duties of care and loyalty to each other and to the LLC. 2. Manager-managed LLCs 2.1 In a manager-managed LLC, only managers owe fiduciary duties of care and loyalty to the LLC and, where applicable, to the members. 2.2 Non-managing members generally do not owe these fiduciary duties simply by virtue of being members. 2.3 The members can ratify a manager’s act that would otherwise violate the duty of loyalty, typically with informed approval under the operating agreement and applicable statute. 3. Good faith and fair dealing 3.1 Regardless of whether the LLC is member-managed or manager-managed, all members and managers have an obligation of good faith and fair dealing in the performance and enforcement of the operating agreement. 3.2 This contractual obligation cannot be eliminated, but the operating agreement may define or shape how good faith and fair dealing apply, subject to statutory limits.
cards.frontPrompt: How do fiduciary duties differ between member-managed and manager-managed LLCs, and what obligation of good faith and fair dealing do members and managers owe?
cards.cloze: 1. {{c1::Member-managed LLCs}} 1.1 In a member-managed LLC, all {{c2::members}} generally owe fiduciary duties of {{c3::care}} and {{c4::loyalty}} to each other and to the LLC. 2. {{c5::Manager-managed LLCs}} 2.1 In a manager-managed LLC, only {{c6::managers}} owe fiduciary duties of care and loyalty to the LLC and, where applicable, to the members. 2.2 {{c7::Non-managing members}} generally do not owe these fiduciary duties simply by virtue of being members. 2.3 The members can {{c8::ratify}} a manager’s act that would otherwise violate the {{c9::duty of loyalty}}, typically with informed approval. 3. {{c10::Good faith and fair dealing}} 3.1 Regardless of management structure, all {{c11::members and managers}} have an obligation of {{c12::good faith and fair dealing}} in the performance and enforcement of the operating agreement. 3.2 This obligation generally cannot be {{c13::eliminated}} but may be {{c14::defined or shaped}} in the operating agreement, subject to statutory limits.
cards.easyContent: In a member-managed LLC, all members owe duties of care and loyalty to each other and to the LLC. In a manager-managed LLC, those fiduciary duties are owed by the managers, not by non-managing members. All members and managers, however, must act in good faith and with fair dealing in carrying out the operating agreement.
cards.mediumContent: Fiduciary duties in an LLC depend on its management structure. In a member-managed LLC, every member owes duties of care and loyalty to each other and to the LLC. In a manager-managed LLC, only the designated managers owe these duties; non-managing members typically do not owe fiduciary duties just by holding a membership interest. Members can ratify managers’ actions that would otherwise breach the duty of loyalty with informed approval. Regardless of structure, all members and managers must act in good faith and with fair dealing in performing and enforcing the operating agreement, and this contractual obligation generally cannot be waived outright, though it may be defined in the agreement within statutory limits.
cards.hardContent: In a member-managed LLC, all members function similarly to partners and therefore owe traditional fiduciary duties of care and loyalty to the LLC and to one another. In a manager-managed LLC, however, management authority is centralized in designated managers, and those managers owe fiduciary duties of care and loyalty comparable to corporate directors or general partners; non-managing members ordinarily do not owe such duties merely as passive owners. Acts by managers that would otherwise constitute a breach of the duty of loyalty—such as self-dealing or usurping LLC opportunities—can often be cleansed by informed ratification by the members, as permitted by the operating agreement and applicable statute. Separate from fiduciary duties, all members and managers in an LLC are bound by an implied contractual obligation of good faith and fair dealing in the performance and enforcement of the operating agreement. While the operating agreement may specify how good faith and fair dealing apply in particular contexts, most LLC statutes provide that this obligation cannot be completely eliminated.
cards.mnemonic: Members manage, members owe; managers manage, managers owe; all owe good faith.
cards.clozeLite: In a {{c1::member-managed LLC}}, all {{c2::members owe duties of care and loyalty}}. In a {{c3::manager-managed LLC}}, only {{c4::managers owe those fiduciary duties}}. {{c5::All members and managers owe good faith and fair dealing}}.
